NUMB: To make numb; to deprive of the power of sensation or motion;to render senseless or inert; to deaden; to benumb; to stupefy.For lazy winter numbs the laboring hand. Dryden.Like dull narcotics, numbing pain. Tennyson.
NEMOPHILIST: One who is fond of forest or forest scenery; a haunter of thewoods. [R.]
NARRATE: To tell, rehearse, or recite, as a story; to relate theparticulars of; to go through with in detail, as an incident ortransaction; to give an account of.
NIPPING: Biting; pinching; painful; destructive; as, a nipping frost; anipping wind.
NAKEDNESS: The privy parts; the genitals.Ham ... saw the nakedness of his father. Gen. ix. 22.
NEZ PERCES: A tribe of Indians, mostly inhabiting Idaho.
NEGLIGENT: Apt to neglect; customarily neglectful; characterized bynegligence; careless; heedless; culpably careless; showing lack ofattention; as, disposed in negligent order. "Be thou negligent offame." Swift.He that thinks he can afford to be negligent is not far from beingpoor. Rambler.
NEAR-LEGGED: Having the feet so near together that they interfere intraveling. Shak.
NORTHEASTERLY: Pertaining to the northeast; toward the northeast, or comingfrom the northeast.
NAPPE: Sheet; surface; all that portion of a surface that iscontinuous in such a way that it is possible to pass from any onepoint of the portion to any other point of the portion withoutleaving the surface. Thus, some hyperboloids have one nappe, and somehave two.
NOTOTHERIUM: An extinct genus of gigantic herbivorous marsupials, found inthe Pliocene formation of Australia.
NERVOMUSCULAR: Of or pertaining to both nerves and muscles; of the nature ofnerves and muscles; as, nervomuscular energy.
NEBULAR: Of or pertaining to nebulæ; of the nature of, or resembling, anebula. Nebular hypothesis, an hypothesis to explain the process offormation of the stars and planets, presented in various forms byKant, Herschel, Laplace, and others. As formed by Laplace, itsupposed the matter of the solar system to have existed originally inthe form of a vast, diffused, revolving nebula, which, graduallycooling and contracting, threw off, in obedience to mechanical andphysical laws, succesive rings of matter, from which subsequently, bythe same laws, were produced the several planets, satellites, andother bodies of the system. The phrase may indicate any hypothesisaccording to which the stars or the bodies of the solar system havebeen evolved from a widely diffused nebulous form of matter.
NALE: Ale; also, an alehouse. [Obs.]Great feasts at the nale. Chaucer.
NON-PROS: To decline or fail to prosecute; to allow to be dropped (saidof a suit); to enter judgment against (a plaintiff who fails toprosecute); as, the plaintiff was non-prossed.
NARRABLE: Capable of being narrated or told. [Obs.]
NUTGALL: A more or less round gall resembling a nut, esp. one of thoseproduced on the oak and used in the arts. See Gall, Gallnut.
NUTMEG: The kernel of the fruit of the nutmeg tree (Myristicafragrans), a native of the Molucca Islands, but cultivated elsewherein the tropics.
NOBEL PRIZES: Prizes for the encouragement of men and women who work for theinterests of humanity, established by the will of A. B. Nobel (1833-96), the Swedish inventor of dynamite, who left his entire estate forthis purpose. They are awarded yearly for what is regarded as themost important work during the year in physics, chemistry, medicineor physiology, idealistic literature, and service in the interest ofpeace. The prizes, averaging $40,000 each, were first awarded in1901.
NASEBERRY: A tropical fruit. See Sapodilla. [Written also nisberry.]
NOSOPHEN: An iodine compound obtained as a yellowish gray, odorless,tasteless powder by the action of iodine on phenolphthalein.
NEGROHEAD: An inferior commercial variety of India rubber made up intoround masses.
NATURALNESS: The state or quality of being natural; conformity to nature.
NIGGERHEAD: A strong black chewing tobacco, usually in twisted plug form;negro head.
NONMEDULLATED: Not medullated; (Anat.) without a medulla or marrow, or withouta medullary sheath; as, a nonmedullated nerve fiber.
NICAGUA: The laughing falcon. See under laughing.
NUT: The fruit of certain trees and shrubs (as of the almond,walnut, hickory, beech, filbert, etc.), consisting of a hard andindehiscent shell inclosing a kernel.
NEBULATED: Clouded with indistinct color markings, as an animal.
NECROMANCY: The art of revealing future events by means of a pretendedcommunication with the dead; the black art; hence, magic in general;conjuration; enchantment. See Black art.This palace standeth in the air, By necromancy placèd there. Drayton.
NEAP: The tongue or pole of a cart or other vehicle drawn by twoanimals. [U.S.]
NITRYL: A name sometimes given to the nitro group or radical.
NIDUS: A nest: a repository for the eggs of birds, insects, etc.; abreeding place; esp., the place or substance where parasites or thegerms of a disease effect lodgment or are developed.
NOOSE: A running knot, or loop, which binds the closer the more it isdrawn.
NEUROPORE: An opening at either end of the embryonic neural canal.
NOVUM: A game at dice, properly called novem quinque (L., nine five),the two principal throws being nine and five. [Obs.] Shak.
NIGHT-EYED: Capable of seeing at night; sharp-eyed. "Your night-eyedTiberius." B. Jonson.
NOMADIZE: To lead the life of a nomad; to wander with flocks and herdsfor the sake of finding pasturage.The Vogules nomadize chiefly about the Rivers Irtish, Obi, Kama, andVolga. W. Tooke.
NEPHROSTOME: The funnelshaped opening of a nephridium into the body cavity.
NOUMENAL: Of or pertaining to the noumenon; real; -- opposed tophenomenal. G. H. Lewes.
NUNCHION: A portion of food taken at or after noon, usually between fullmeals; a luncheon. [Written also noonshun.] Hudibras.
NOTOBRANCHIATE: Of or pertaining to the Notobranchiata.
NONANE: One of a group of metameric hydrocarbons C9H20 of the paraffinseries; -- so called because of the nine carbon atoms in themolecule. Normal nonane is a colorless volatile liquid, an ingredientof ordinary kerosene.
NUMERIST: One who deals in numbers. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
NUDUM PACTUM: A bare, naked contract, without any consideration. Tomlins.
NASOPHARYNGEAL: Of or pertaining to both throat and nose; as, a nasopharyngealpolypus.
NISUS: A striving; an effort; a conatus.A nisus or energizing towards a presented object. Hickok.
NURSLING: One who, or that which, is nursed; an infant; a fondling.I was his nursling once, and choice delight. Milton.
NORSE: Of or pertaining to ancient Scandinavia, or to the languagespoken by its inhabitants.
NIZAM: The title of the native sovereigns of Hyderabad, in India,since 1719.
NULLIBIETY: The state or condition of being nowhere. [Obs.]
NITROHYDROCHLORIC: Of, pertaining to, or containing, nitric and hydrochloricacids. Nitrohydrochloric acid, a mixture of nitric and hydrochloricacids, usually in the proportion of one part of the former to threeof the latter, and remarkable for its solvent action on gold andplatinum; -- called also nitromuriatic acid, and aqua regia.
NODATED: Knotted. Nodated hyperbola (Geom.), a certain curve of thethird order having two branches which cross each other, forming anode.
NEOCRITICISM: The form of Neo-Kantianism developed by French idealists,following C. Renouvier.  It rejects the noumena of Kant, restrictingknowledge to phenomena as constituted by a priori categories.
NUBIGENOUS: Born of, or produced from, clouds. [R.]
NEEDLER: One who makes or uses needles; also, a dealer in needles. PiersPlowman.
NITRO-: A combining form (used also adjectively) designating certaincompounds of nitrogen or of its acids, as nitrohydrochloric,nitrocalcite; also, designating the group or radical NO2, or itscompounds, as nitrobenzene. Nitro group, the radical NO2; -- calledalso nitroxyl.
NIDOROUS: Resembling the smell or taste of roast meat, or of corruptanimal matter. [R.]
NONAPPEARANCE: Default of apperance, as in court, to prosecute or defend;failure to appear.
NUNNISH: Of, pertaining to, or resembling a nun; characteristic of anun.-- Nun"nish*ness, n.
NOISELESS: Making, or causing, no noise or bustle; without noise; silent;as, the noiseless foot of time.So noiseless would I live. Dryden.-- Noise"less*ly, adv.-- Noise"less*ness, n.
NEO-: A prefix meaning new, recent, late; and in chemistrydesignating specifically that variety of metameric hydrocarbonswhich, when the name was applied, had been recently classified, andin which at least one carbon atom in connected directly with fourother carbon atoms; -- contrasted with normal and iso-; as,neopentane; the neoparaffins. Also used adjectively.
NAUTICALLY: In a nautical manner; with reference to nautical affais.
NIRVANA: In the Buddhist system of religion, the final emancipation ofthe soul from transmigration, and consequently a beatificenfrachisement from the evils of wordly existence, as by annihilationor absorption into the divine. See Buddhism.
NIGRITIC: Pertaining to, or having the characteristics of, negroes, or ofthe Negritos, Papuans, and the Melanesian races; negritic.
NEGOTIOUS: Very busy; attentive to business; active. [R.] D. Rogers.
NARCISSUS: A genus of endogenous bulbous plants with handsome flowers,having a cup-shaped crown within the six-lobed perianth, andcomprising the daffodils and jonquils of several kinds.
NUGIFY: To render trifling or futile; to make silly. [R.] Coleridge.
NASALITY: The quality or state of being nasal.
NEUROPTERIS: An extensive genus of fossil ferns, of which species have beenfound from the Devonian to the Triassic formation.
NICKER TREE: The plant producing nicker nuts. [Written also neckar tree andnickar tree.]
NOY: To annoy; to vex. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.] Piers Plowman.All that noyed his heavy spright. Spenser.
NAVEL ORANGE: A type of orange in which the fruit incloses a small secondaryfruit, the rind showing on the exterior a navel-like pit ordepression at the apex. There are several varieties; they are usuallyseedless, or nearly so, and are much grown in California.
NATIVITY: A picture representing or symbolizing the early infancy ofChrist. The simplest form is the babe in a rude cradle, and the headsof an ox and an ass to express the stable in which he was born.
NOISETTE: A hybrid rose produced in 1817, by a French gardener, Noisette,of Charleston, South Carolina, from the China rose and the musk rose.It has given rise to many fine varieties, as the Lamarque, theMarechal (or Marshal) Niel, and the Cloth of gold. Most roses of thisclass have clustered flowers and are of vigorous growth. P.Henderson.
NAVVY: Originally, a laborer on canals for internal navigation; hence,a laborer on other public works, as in building railroads,embankments, etc. [Eng.]
NESTLING: Newly hatched; being yet in the nest.
NEOLOGIZATION: The act or process of neologizing.
NEARNESS: The state or quality of being near; -- used in the varioussenses of the adjective.
NEUROPATHIC: Of or pertaining to neuropathy; of the nature of, or sufferingfrom, nervous disease.
NETSUKE: In Japanese costume and decorative art, a small object carvedin wood, ivory, bone, or horn, or wrought in metal, and pierced withholes for cords by which it is connected, for convenience, with theinro, the smoking pouch (tabako-ire), and similar objects carried inthe girdle. It is now much used on purses sold in Europe and America.
NECROPHOBIA: An exaggerated fear of death or horror of dead bodies.
NUBILE: Of an age suitable for marriage; marriageable. Prior.
NUCHAL: Of, pertaining to, or in the region of, the back, or nape, ofthe neck; -- applied especially to the anterior median plate in thecarapace of turtles.
NURSE: A lieutenant or first officer, who is the real commander whenthe captain is unfit for his place.
NOGGEN: Made of hemp; hence, hard; rough; harsh. [Obs.] Johnson.
NEUROLOGIST: One who is versed in neurology; also, one skilled in thetreatment of nervous diseases.
NOPAL: A cactaceous plant (Nopalea cochinellifera), originallyMexican, on which the cochineal insect feeds, and from which it iscollected. The name is sometimes given to other species of Cactaceæ.
NITROUS: Of, pertaining to, or designating, any one of those compoundsin which nitrogen has a relatively lower valence as contrasted withnitric compounds. Nitrous acid (Chem.), a hypothetical acid ofnitrogen HNO2, not known in the free state, but forming a well knownseries of salts, viz., the nitrites.-- Nitrous oxide. See Laughing gas.
NAINSOOK: A thick sort of jaconet muslin, plain or striped, formerly madein India.
NYCTITROPIC: Turning or bending at night into special positions.
NUCLEOLATED: Having a nucleole, or second inner nucleus.
NAG: To tease in a petty way; to scold habitually; to annoy; to fretpertinaciously. [Colloq.] "She never nagged." J. Ingelow.
NATURALIZATION: The act or process of naturalizing, esp. of investing an alienwith the rights and privileges of a native or citizen; also, thestate of being naturalized.
NEMEAN: Of or pertaining to Nemea, in Argolis, where the ancient Greekscelebrated games, and Hercules killed a lion.
NEBULA: A faint, cloudlike, self-luminous mass of matter situatedbeyond the solar system among the stars. True nebulæ are gaseous; butvery distant star clusters often appear like them in the telescope.
NARRATIVE: That which is narrated; the recital of a story; a continuousaccount of the particulars of an event or transaction; a story.Cyntio was much taken with my narrative. Tatler.
NECKTIE: A scarf, band, or kerchief of silk, etc., passing around theneck or collar and tied in front; a bow of silk, etc., fastened infront of the neck.
NYENTEK: A carnivorous mannual (Helictis moscatus, or H. orientalis),native of Eastern Asia and the Indies. It has a dorsal white stripe,and another one across the shoulders. It has a strong musky odor.
NAIK: A chief; a leader; a Sepoy corporal. Balfour (Cyc. of India).
NOTIDANIAN: Any one of several species of sharks of the family Notidanidæ,or Hexanchidæ. Called also cow sharks. See Shark.
NONMEMBERSHIP: State of not being a member.
NEO-GREEK: A member of a body of French painters (F. les néo-Grecs) of themiddle 19th century. The term is rather one applied by outsiders tocertain artists of grave and refined style, such as Hamon and Aubert,than a name adopted by the artists themselves.
NEPETA: A genus of labiate plants, including the catnip and ground ivy.
NECKERCHIEF: A kerchief for the neck; -- called also neck handkerchief.
NEPHRITE: A hard compact mineral, of a dark green color, formerly worn asa remedy for diseases of the kidneys, whence its name; kidney stone;a kind of jade. See Jade.
NUCAMENTACEOUS: Like a nut either in structure or in being indehiscent; bearingone-seeded nutlike fruits. [Written also nucumentaceous.]
NIHILITY: Nothingness; a state of being nothing.
NIELLO: A process, now no longer used, invented by J. N. Niepce, aFrench chemist, in 1829. It depends upon the action of light inrendering a thin layer of bitumen, with which the plate is coated,insoluble.
NARRATORY: Giving an account of events; narrative; as, narratory letters.Howell.
NONUNIFORMIST: One who believes that past changes in the structure of theearth have proceeded from cataclysms or causes more violent than arenow operating; -- called also nonuniformitarian.
NEPOTAL: Of or relating to a nephew.
NOISINESS: The state or quality of being noisy.
NEUROTOMY: The division of a nerve, for the relief of neuralgia, or forother purposes. Dunglison.
NORTHEAST: The point between the north and east, at an equal distance fromeach; the northeast part or region.
NORWEGIAN: Of or pertaining to Norway, its inhabitants, or its language.
NEWFANGLE: Eager for novelties; desirous of changing. [Obs.]So newfangel be they of their meat. Chaucer.
NITROPRUSSIC: Pertaining to, derived from, or designating, a complex acidcalled nitroprussic acid, obtained indirectly by the action of nitricacid on potassium ferrocyanide (yellow prussiate), as a redcrystalline unstable substance. It forms salts called nitroprussides,which give a rich purple color with alkaline subphides.
NON SEQUITUR: An inference which does not follow from the premises.
NONPRODUCTION: A failure to produce or exhibit.
NONNITROGNOUS: Devoid of nitrogen; as, a nonnitrogenous principle; anonnitrogenous food. See the Note under Food, n., 1.
NIGHTGOWN: A loose gown used for undress; also, a gown used for a sleepinggarnment.
NATATORIAL: Inclined or adapted to swim; swimming; as, natatorial birds.
NATURIZE: To endow with a nature or qualities; to refer to nature. [Obs.]B. Jonson.
NAMESAKE: One that has the same name as another; especially, one calledafter, or named out of regard to, another.
NATURELESS: Not in accordance with nature; unnatural. [Obs.] Milton.
NOUNAL: Of or pertaining to a noun.Verbs which in whole or in part have shed their old nounal coat.Earle.
NULL: Of no legal or binding force or validity; of no efficacy;invalid; void; nugatory; useless.Faultily faultless, icily regular, splendidly null, Dead perfection;no more. Tennyson.
NURSING: Supplying or taking nourishment from, or as from, the breast;as, a nursing mother; a nursing infant.
NUTRITIOUS: Nourishing; promoting growth, or preventing decay; alimental.-- Nu*tri"tious*ly, adv.-- Nu*tri"tious*ness, n.
NASOBUCCAL: Connected with both the nose and the mouth; as, the nasobuccalgroove in the skate.
NEOTROPICAL: Belonging to, or designating, a region of the earth's surfacewhich comprises most of South America, the Antilles, and tropicalNorth America.
NONYLENE: Any one of a series of metameric, unsaturated hydrocarbonsC9H18 of the ethylene series.
NOWD: The European gray gurnard (Trigla gurnardus). [Written alsoknoud.]
NEOCOMIAN: A term applied to the lowest deposits of the Cretaceous orchalk formation of Europe, being the lower greensand.
NATURALISM: The doctrine of those who deny a supernatural agency in themiracles and revelations recorded in the Bible, and in spiritualinfluences; also, any system of philosophy which refers the phenomenaof nature to a blind force or forces acting necessarily or accordingto fixed laws, excluding origination or direction by one intelligentwill.
NYMPHISH: Relating to nymphs; ladylike. "Nymphish war." Drayton.
NEFASCH: Any fish of the genus Distichodus. Several large speciesinhabit the Nile.
NIGHTSHIRT: A kind of nightgown for men.
NATICOID: Like or belonging to Natica, or the family Naticæ.
NICKER NUT: A rounded seed, rather smaller than a nutmeg, having a hardsmooth shell, and a yellowish or bluish color. The seeds grow in theprickly pods of tropical, woody climbers of the genus Cæsalpinia. C.Bonduc has yellowish seeds; C.Bonducella, bluish gray. [Spelt alsoneckar nut, nickar nut.]
NON LIQUET: It is not clear; -- a verdict given by a jury when a matter isto be deferred to another day of trial.
NUNNERY: A house in which nuns reside; a cloister or convent in whichwomen reside for life, under religious vows. See Cloister, andConvent.
NONSEXUAL: Having no distinction of sex; sexless; neuter.
NASCAL: A kind of pessary of medicated wool or cotton, formerly used.
NON-: A prefix used in the sense of not; un-; in-; as innonattention, or non-attention, nonconformity, nonmetallic, nonsuit.
NITROGEN: A colorless nonmetallic element, tasteless and odorless,comprising four fifths of the atmosphere by volume. It is chemicallyvery inert in the free state, and as such is incapable of supportinglife (hence the name azote still used by French chemists); but itforms many important compounds, as ammonia, nitric acid, thecyanides, etc, and is a constituent of all organized living tissues,animal or vegetable. Symbol N. Atomic weight 14. It was formerlyregarded as a permanent noncondensible gas, but was liquefied in 1877by Cailletet of Paris, and Pictet of Geneva.
NONEXECUTION: Neglect or failure of execution; nonperformance.
NEOCENE: More recent than the Eocene, that is, including both theMiocene and Pliocene divisions of the Tertiary.
NEIGH: The cry of a horse; a whinny.
NEE: Born; -- a term sometimes used in introducing the name of thefamily to which a married woman belongs by birth; as, Madame deStaël, née Necker.
NERITE: Any mollusk of the genus Nerita.
NIBBLER: One who, or that which, nibbles.
NEMORAL: Of or pertaining to a wood or grove. [R.]
NOLLE PROSEQUI: Will not prosecute; -- an entry on the record, denoting that aplaintiff discontinues his suit, or the attorney for the public aprosecution; either wholly, or as to some count, or as to some ofseveral defendants.
NOM: Name. Nom de guerre (, literally, war name; hence, a fictitiousname, or one assumed for a time.-- Nom de plume (, literally, pen name; hence, a name assumed by anauthor as his or her signature.
NUANCE: A shade of difference; a delicate gradation.
NOTELET: A little or short note; a billet.
NUBBLE: To beat or bruise with the fist. [Obs.] Ainsworth.
NUPHAR: A genus of plants found in the fresh-water ponds or lakes ofEurope, Asia, and North America; the yellow water lily. Cf. Nymphaea.
NONAGRIAN: Any moth of the genus Nonagria and allied genera, as thespindleworm and stalk borer.
NONACQUAINTANCE: Want of acquaintance; the state of being unacquainted.
NOR: A negative connective or particle, introducing the secondmember or clause of a negative proposition, following neither, ornot, in the first member or clause (as or in affirmative propositionsfollows either). Nor is also used sometimes in the first member forneither, and sometimes the neither is omitted and implied by the useof nor.Provide neither gold nor silver, nor brass, in your purses, nor scripfor your journey. Matt. x. 9, 10.Where neither moth nor rust doth corrupt. Matt. vi. 20.I love him not, nor fear him. Shak.Where neither party is nor true, nor kind. Shak.Simois nor Xanthus shall be wanting there. Dryden.
NEWFANGLIST: One who is eager for novelties or desirous of change. [Obs.]Tooker.
NEANDERTHALOID: Like, or pertaining to, the Neanderthal skull, or the type ofman it represents.
NASOSEPTAL: Of or pertaining to the internasal septum.
NONEFFECTIVE: Not fit or available for duty.
NARCOTISM: Narcosis; the state of being narcotized. G. Eliot.
NEDDER: An adder. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.] Chaucer.
NITROXYL: The group NO2, usually called the nitro group.
NASTINESS: The quality or state of being nasty; extreme filthness;dirtiness; also, indecency; obscenity.The nastiness of Plautus and Aristophanes. Dryden.
NEGUS: A beverage made of wine, water, sugar, nutmeg, and lemon juice;-- so called, it is said, from its first maker, Colonel Negus.
NUTRITION: In the broadest sense, a process or series of processes bywhich the living organism as a whole (or its component parts ororgans) is maintained in its normal condition of life and growth.
NILOMETER: An instrument for measuring the rise of water in the Nileduring its periodical flood.
NEO-LATIN: Applied to the Romance languages, as being mostly of Latinorigin.
NEMERTEAN: Of or pertaining to the Nemertina.-- n.
NECROLATRY: The worship of the dead; manes worship. H. Spenser.
NODATION: Act of making a knot, or state of being knotted. [R.]
NEATLY: In a neat manner; tidily; tastefully.
NEARLY: In a near manner; not remotely; closely; intimately; almost.
NOMINALISTIC: Of or pertaining to the Nominalists.
NAUSEA: Seasickness; hence, any similar sickness of the stomachaccompanied with a propensity to vomit; qualm; squeamishness of thestomach; loathing.
NORM: A typical, structural unit; a type. Agassiz.
NAME: To designate (a member) by name, as the Speaker does by way ofreprimand.
NOTATE: Marked with spots or lines, which are often colored. Henslow.
NORTHEASTERN: Of or pertaining to the northeast; northeasterly.
NOTCHING: A method of joining timbers, scantling, etc., by notching them,as at the ends, and overlapping or interlocking the notched portions.
NECROBIOTIC: Of or pertaining to necrobiosis; as, a necrobioticmetamorphosis.
NUGGET: A lump; a mass, esp. a native lump of a precious metal; as, anugget of gold.
NEUROPTERAL: Of or pertaining to the Neuroptera.
NORTHWEST: The point in the horizon between the north and west, andequally distant from each; the northwest part or region.
NEUROSIS: A functional nervous affection or disease, that is, a diseaseof the nerves without any appreciable change of nerve structure.
NILE: The great river of Egypt. Nile bird. (Zoöl.) (a) The wryneck.[Prov. Eng.] (b) The crocodile bird.-- Nile goose (Zoöl.), the Egyptian goose. See Note under Goose, 2.
NOCTIVAGANT: Going about in the night; night-wandering.
NATANT: Floating in water, as the leaves of water lilies, or submersed,as those of many aquatic plants.
NATAL PLUM: The drupaceous fruit of two South African shrubs of the genusArduina (A. bispinosa and A. grandiflora).
NONUSER: Neglect or omission to use an easement or franchise or toassert a right. Kent.
NURSERYMAN: One who cultivates or keeps a nursery, or place for rearingtrees, etc.
NINE: Eight and one more; one less than ten; as, nine miles. Ninemen's morris. See Morris.-- Nine points circle (Geom.), a circle so related to any giventriangle as to pass through the three points in which theperpendiculars from the angles of the triangle upon the oppositesides (or the sides produced) meet the sides. It also passes throughthe three middle points of the sides of the triangle and through thethree middle points of those parts of the perpendiculars that arebetween their common point of meeting and the angles of the triangle.The circle is hence called the nine points or six points circle.
NET: A figure made up of a large number of straight lines or curves,which are connected at certain points and related to each other bysome specified law.
NIGGLING: Finicky or pottering work; specif. (Fine Arts),
NONCONDUCTING: Not conducting; not transmitting a fluid or force; thus, inelectricity, wax is a nonconducting substance.
NUMERALLY: According to number; in number; numerically.
NIOBE: The daughter of Tantalus, and wife of Amphion, king of Thebes.Her pride in her children provoked Apollo and Diana, who slew themall. Niobe herself was changed by the gods into stone.
NITROMETER: An apparatus for determining the amount of nitrogen or some ofits compounds in any substance subjected to analysis; an azotometer.
NITRATED: Combined, or impregnated, with nitric acid, or some of itscompounds.
NECTAREAN: Resembling nectar; very sweet and pleasant. "nectarean juice."Talfourd.
NOMINALLY: In a nominal manner; by name; in name only; not in reality.Burke.
NAILBRUSH: A brush for cleaning the nails.
NUL: No; not any; as, nul disseizin; nul tort.
NEOGEN: An alloy resembling silver, and consisting chiefly of copper,zinc, and nickel, with small proportions of tin, aluminium, andbismuth. Ure.
NUCLEOPLASM: The matter composing the nucleus of a cell; the protoplasm ofthe nucleus; karyoplasma.
NECROPHAGOUS: Of or pertaining to the Necrophaga; eating carrion. SeeNecrophagan.
NOMINATIVE: Giving a name; naming; designating; -- said of that case orform of a noun which stands as the subject of a finite verb.-- n.
NIGRANILINE: The complex, nitrogenous, organic base and dyestuff called alsoaniline black.
NEURALGIC: of or pertaining to, or having the character of, neuralgia; as,a neuralgic headache.
NIDULATION: The time of remaining in the nest. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
NEUTRALIZER: One who, or that which, neutralizes; that which destroys,disguises, or renders inert the peculiar properties of a body.
NOIL: A short or waste piece or knot of wool separated from thelonger staple by combing; also, a similar piece or shred of wastesilk.
NURSEMAID: A girl employed to attend children.
NONIMPORTATION: Want or failure of importation; a not importing of commodities.
NARES: The nostrils or nasal openings, -- the anterior nares being theexternal or proper nostrils, and the posterior nares, the openings ofthe nasal cavities into the mouth or pharynx.
NEOTERISM: An innovation or novelty; a neoteric word or phrase.
NONUSANCE: Neglect of using; failure to use. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
NOTCHWEED: A foul-smelling weed, the stinking goosefoot (ChenopodiumVulvaria).
NEEDLEBOOK: A book-shaped needlecase, having leaves of cloth into which theneedles are stuck.
NONUNIONIST: One who does not belong, or refuses to belong, to a tradesunion.
NYCTITROPISM: The tendency of certain plant organs, as leaves, to assumespecial "sleeping" positions or make curvatures under the influenceof darkness. It is well illustrated in the leaflets of clover andother leguminous plants.
NEOTERIST: One ho introduces new word Fitzed Hall.
NUMERICALLY: In a numerical manner; in numbers; with respect to number, orsameness in number; as, a thing is numerically the same, ornumerically different.
NOMIC: Customary; ordinary; -- applied to the usual English spelling,in distinction from strictly phonetic methods. H Sweet.-- n.
NICOTIDINE: A complex, oily, nitrogenous base, isomeric with nicotine, andobtained by the reduction of certain derivatives of the pyridinegroup.
NONCOMPLIANCE: Neglect of compliance; failure to comply.
NEMALINE: Having the form of threads; fibrous.
NEVE: The upper part of a glacier, above the limit or perpetual snow.See Galcier.
NAZARITE: A Jew bound by a vow to lave the hair uncut, to abstain fromwine and strong drink, and to practice extraordinary purity of lifeand devotion, the obligation being for life, or for a certain time.The word is also used adjectively.
NONAGESIMAL: Of or pertaining to the ninetieth degree or to a nonagesimal.
NUISANCER: One who makes or causes a nuisance.
NON OBSTANTE: A clause in old English statutes and letters patent, importinga license from the crown to do a thing notwithstanding any statute tothe contrary. This dispensing power was abolished by the Bill ofRights.In this very reign [Henry III.] the practice of dispensing withstatutes by a non obstante was introduced. Hallam.Non obstante veredicto Etym: [LL.] (Law), a judgment sometimesentered by order of the court, for the plaintiff, notwithstanding averdict for the defendant. Stephen.
NICOTINE: An alkaloid which is the active principle of tobacco. It is acolorless, transparent, oily liquid, having an acrid odor, and anacrid burning taste. It is intensely poisonous. Ure.
NAID: Any one of numerous species of small, fresh-water, chætopodannelids of the tribe Naidina. They belong to the Oligochæta.
NONSENSICAL: Without sense; unmeaning; absurb; foolish; irrational;preposterous.-- Non*sen"si*cal*ly, adv.-- Non*sen"si*cal*ness, n.
NEWS-LETTER: A circular letter, written or printed for the purpose ofdisseminating news. This was the name given to the earliest Englishnewspapers.
NEFARIOUS: Wicked in the extreme; abominable; iniquitous; atrociouslyvillainous; execrable; detestably vile.
NUNCIATE: One who announces; a messenger; a nuncio. [Obs.] Hoole.
NOSEBAG: A bag in which feed for a horse, ox, or the like, may befastened under the nose by a string passing over the head.
NEMATOCYST: A lasso cell, or thread cell. See Lasso cell, under Lasso.
NUTSHELL: A shell of the genus Nucula. To be, or lie, in a nutshell, tobe within a small compass; to admit of very brief or simpledetermination or statement. "The remedy lay in a nutshell." Macaulay.
NASIFORM: Having the shape of a nose.
NIGHTFALL: The close of the day. Swift.
NECK: A reduction in size near the end of an object, formed by agroove around it; as, a neck forming the journal of a shaft.
NATCH: The rump of beef; esp., the lower and back part of the rump.Natch bone, the edgebone, or aitchbone, in beef.
NICENESS: Quality or state of being nice.
NITROCALCITE: Nitrate of calcium, a substance having a grayish white color,occuring in efforescences on old walls, and in limestone caves,especially where there exists decaying animal matter.
NOVATIANISM: The doctrines or principles of the Novatians. Milner.
NICKELINE: An alloy of nickel, a variety of German silver.
NICKING: Small coal produced in making the nicking.
NECKCLOTH: A piece of any fabric worn around the neck.
NONCOMPLETION: Lack of completion; failure to complete.
NANNY: A diminutive of Ann or Anne, the proper name. Nanny goat, afemale goat. [Colloq.]
NILL: Not to will; to refuse; to reject. [Obs.]Certes, said he, I nill thine offered grace. Spenser.
NIGGARDLINESS: The quality or state of being niggard; meanness in giving orspending; parsimony; stinginess.Niggardliness is not good husbandry. Addison.
NONVERNACULAR: Not vernacular.A nonvernacular expression. Sir W. Hamilton.
NAEVOID: Resembling a nævus or nævi; as, nævoid elephantiasis.Dunglison.
NEO-KANTIANISM: The philosophy of modern thinkers who follow Kant in hisgeneral theory of knowledge, esp. of a group of German philosophersincluding F. A. Lange, H. Cohen, Paul Natorp, and others.
NIP: A sip or small draught; esp., a draught of intoxicating liquor;a dram.
NARRATION: That part of a discourse which recites the time, manner, orconsequences of an action, or simply states the facts connected withthe subject.
NEOGRAMMARIAN: One of a group of philologists who apply phonetic laws morewidely and strictly than was formerly done, and who maintain thatthese laws admit of no real exceptions. --Ne`o*gram*mat"ic*al (#), a.
NOSED: Having a nose, or such a nose; -- chieflay used in composition;as, pug-nosed.
NOTAEUM: The back or upper surface, as of a bird.
NONCOMBATANT: Any person connected with an army, or within the lines of anarmy, who does not make it his business to fight, as any one of themedical officers and their assistants, chaplains, and others; also,any of the citizens of a place occupied by an army; also, any oneholding a similar position with respect to the navy.
NEGLECTIVE: Neglectful. [R.] "Neglective of their own children." Fuller.
NAPIFORM: Turnip-shaped; large and round in the upper part, and veryslender below.
NONALIENATION: Failure to alienate; also, the state of not being alienated.
NEPENTHE: A drug used by the ancients to give relief from pain andsorrow; -- by some supposed to have been opium or hasheesh. Hence,anything soothing and comforting.Lulled with the sweet nepenthe of a court. Pope.Quaff, O quaff this kind nepenthe. Poe.
NAVIGABILITY: The quality or condition of being navigable; navigableness.
NODDING: Curved so that the apex hangs down; having the top bentdownward.
NUTRICATION: The act or manner of feeding. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
NITRIARY: An artificial bed of animal matter for the manufacture of niterby nitrification. See Nitrification, 2.
NOVENARY: Of or pertaining to the number nine.
NEUROSKELETON: The deep-seated parts of the vertebrate skeleton which arerelation with the nervous axis and locomation. Owen.
NURSEPOND: A pond where fish are fed. Walton.
NUTRIA: The fur of the coypu. See Coypu.
NAUSEOUS: Causing, or fitted to cause, nausea; sickening; loathsome;disgusting; exciting abhorrence; as, a nauseous drug or medicine.-- Nau"seous*ly, adv.-- Nau"seous*ness, n.The nauseousness of such company disgusts a reasonable man. Dryden.
NOYADE: A drowning of many persons at once, -- a method of executionpracticed at Nantes in France during the Reign of Terror, by JeanBaptiste Carrier.
NEOPLASTIC: of or pertaining to neoplasty, or neoplasia.
NINETY: Nine times ten; eighty-nine and one more; as, ninety men.
NEOMENIA: The time of the new moon; the beginning of the month in thelunar calendar.
NEPHELOMETER: An instrument for measuring or registering the amount ofcloudiness.
NECROBIOSIS: The death of a part by molecular disintegration and withoutloss of continuity, as in the processes of degeneration and atrophy.Virchow.
NEREID: A sea nymph, one of the daughters of Nereus, who wereattendants upon Neptune, and were represented as riding on seahorses, sometimes with the human form entire, and sometimes with thetail of a fish.
NATATION: The act of floating on the water; swimming. Sir T. Browne.
NOMANCY: The art or practice of divining the destiny of persons by theletters which form their names.
NYCTOPHILE: Any Australian bat of the genus Nyctophilus, having a verysimple nasal appendage.
NUMBERS: of Number. The fourth book of the Pentateuch, containing thecensus of the Hebrews.
NOTIONALITY: A notional or groundless opinion. [R.] Glanvill.
NITROGELATIN: An explosive consisting of gun cotton and camphor dissolved innitroglycerin. [Written also nitrogelatine.]
NOTEWORTHY: Worthy of observation or notice; remarkable.
NIDE: A nestful; a brood; as, a nide of pheasants. [Obs.]
NOMOCRACY: Government in accordance with a system of law. Milman.
NONCONDENSING: Not condensing; discharging the steam from the cylinder at apressure nearly equal to or above that of the atmosphere and not intoa condenser.
NONCOMMITTAL: A state of not being committed or pledged; forbearance orrefusal to commit one's self. Also used adjectively.
NAUMACHY: A show or spectacle representing a sea fight; also, a place forsuch exhibitions.
NEO-DARWINISM: The theory which holds natural selection, as explained byDarwin, to be the chief factor in the evolution of plants andanimals, and denies the inheritance of acquired characters; -- esp.opposed to Neo-Lamarckism. Weismannism is an example of extreme Neo-Darwinism. -- Ne`o-Dar*win"i*an, a. & n.
NERVE: One of the whitish and elastic bundles of fibers, with theaccompanying tissues, which transmit nervous impulses between nervecenters and various parts of the animal body.
NEO-HEGELIANISM: The philosophy of a school of British and American idealistswho follow Hegel in dialectical or logical method and in the generaloutcome of their doctrine. The founders and leaders of Neo-Hegelianism include: in England, T. H. Green (1836-1882); inScotland, J. (1820-98) and E. (1835-1908) Caird; in the UnitedStates, W. T. Harris (1835-1909) and Josiah Royce (1855- -).
NOMINALISM: The principles or philosophy of the Nominalists.
NEBALIA: A genus of small marine Crustacea, considered the type of adistinct order (Nebaloidea, or Phyllocarida.)
NEGLECTFUL: Full of neglect; heedless; careless; negligent; inattentive;indifferent. Pope.A cold and neglectful countenance. Locke.Though the Romans had no great genius for trade, yet they were notentirely neglectful of it. Arbuthnot.-- Neg*lect"ful*ly, adv.-- Neg*lect"ful*ness, n.
NEURINE: A poisonous organic base (a ptomaine) formed in thedecomposition of protagon with boiling baryta water, and in theputrefraction of proteid matter. It was for a long time consideredidentical with choline, a crystalline body originally obtained frombile. Chemically, however, choline is oxyethyl-trimethyl-ammoniumhydroxide, while neurine is vinyl-trimethyl-ammonium hydroxide.[Written also neurin.]
NERVURE: One of the nerves of leaves.
NAVARCH: The commander of a fleet. Mitford.
NORTHMOST: Lying farthest north; northernmost.Northmost part of the coast of Mozambique. De Foe.
NON-EPISCOPAL: Not Episcopal; not pertaining to the Episcopal church orsystem.
NOMADIC: Of or pertaining to nomads, or their way of life; wandering;moving from place to place for subsistence; as, a nomadic tribe.-- No*mad"ic*al*ly, adv.
NATIONALIZE: To make national; to make a nation of; to endow with thecharacter and habits of a nation, or the peculiar sentiments andattachment of citizens of a nation.
NUMBFISH: The torpedo, which numbs by the electric shocks which it gives.
NATIONALIZATION: The act of nationalizing, or the state of being nationalized.
NEOMENOIDEA: A division of vermiform gastropod mollusks, without a shell,belonging to the Isopleura.
NUTHATCH: Any one of several species of birds of the genus Sitta, as theEuropean species (Sitta Europæa). The white-breasted nuthatch (S.Carolinensis), the red-breasted nuthatch (S. Canadensis), the pygmynuthatch (S. pygmæa), and others, are American.
NAGANA: The disease caused by the tsetse fly. [South Africa]
NUNNATION: The pronunciation of n at the end of words.
NONAGE: The ninth part of movable goods, formerly payable to the clergyon the death of persons in their parishes. Mozley & W.
NECTARED: Imbued with nectar; mingled with nectar; abounding with nectar.Milton.
NATURE: To endow with natural qualities. [Obs.]He [God] which natureth every kind. Gower.
NICKELOUS: Of, pertaining to, or designating, those compounds of nickel inwhich, as contrasted with the nickelic compounds, the metal has alower valence; as, nickelous oxide. Frankland.
NOSESMART: A kind of cress, a pungent cruciferous plant, including severalspecies of the genus Nasturtium.
NUTRITIONAL: Of or pertaining to nutrition; as, nutritional changes.
NIDULANT: Lying loose in pulp or cotton within a berry or pericarp, as ina nest.
NEATHOUSE: A building for the shelter of neat cattle. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]Massinger.
NOTOCHORD: An elastic cartilagelike rod which is developed beneath themedullary groove in the vertebrate embryo, and constitutes theprimitive axial skeleton around which the centra of the vertebræ andthe posterior part of the base of the skull are developed; the chordadorsalis. See Illust. of Ectoderm.
NASION: The middle point of the nasofrontal suture.
NORMAL: According to a square or rule; perpendicular; forming a rightangle. Specifically: Of or pertaining to a normal.
NIM: To take; to steal; to filch. [Obs.]This canon it in his hand nam. Chaucer.
NUMMARY: Of or relating to coins or money.
NETTY: Like a net, or network; netted. [R.]
NETHERMOST: Lowest; as, the nethermost abyss. Milton.
NOON-FLOWER: The goat's beard, whose flowers close at midday.
NONCONTENT: One who gives a negative vote; -- sometimes abridged intononcon. or non con.
NUCLEOLUS: A small rounded body contained in the nucleus of a cell or aprotozoan.
NAVARCHY: Nautical skill or experience. [Obs.] ir W. Petty.
NERITA: A genus of marine gastropods, mostly natives of warm climates.
NUMISMATOGRAPHY: A treatise on, or description of, coins and medals.
NOTIONIST: One whose opinions are ungrounded notions. [R.] Bp. Hopkins.
NOLO CONTENDERE: A plea, by the defendant, in a criminal prosecution, which,without admitting guilt, subjects him to all the consequences of aplea of quilty.
NEWS-WRITER: One who gathered news for, and wrote, news-letters. Macaulay.
NARROWER: One who, or that which, narrows or contracts. Hannah More.
NON: No; not. See No, a. Chaucer.
NOBILITATION: The act of making noble. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.
NAVEL: A mark or depression in the middle of the abdomen; theumbilicus. See Umbilicus.belly button in humans
NEPHRIDIAL: of or pertaining to a nephridium.
NOLLEITY: The state of being unwilling; nolition. [R.]
NEOCOSMIC: of or pertaining to the universe in its present state;specifically, pertaining to the races of men known to history.
NAWAB: A deputy ruler or viceroy in India; also, a title given bycourtesy to other persons of high rank in the East.
NATATORY: Adapted for swimming or floating; as, natatory organs.
NONDECANE: A hydrocarbon of the paraffin series, a white waxy substance,C19H40; -- so called from the number of carbon atoms in the molecule.
NOACHIAN: Of or pertaining to the patriarch Noah, or to his time.
NONRESIDENCE: The state or condition of being nonresident, Swift.
NASTURTIUM: A genus of cruciferous plants, having white or yellowishflowers, including several species of cress. They are found chieflyin wet or damp grounds, and have a pungent biting taste.
NUNC DIMITTIS: The song of Simeon (Luke ii. 29-32), used in the ritual of manychurches. It begins with these words in the Vulgate.
NUTANT: Nodding; having the top bent downward.
NEUTER: Having no generative organs, or imperfectly developed ones;sexless. See Neuter, n., 3.
NUTRITIVE: Of or pertaining to nutrition; as, the nutritive functions;having the quality of nourishing; nutritious; nutrimental; alimental;as, nutritive food or berries. Nutritive plasma. (Biol.) SeeIdioplasma.-- Nutritive polyp (Zoöl.), any one of the zooids of a compoundhydroid, or coral, which has a mouth and digestive cavity.-- Nu"tri*tive*ly, adv.-- Nu"tri*tive*ness, n.
NENUPHAR: The great white water lily of Europe; the Nymphæa alba.
NEPHROLITHIC: of or pertaining to gravel, or renal calculi. Dunglison.
NEWFANGLY: In a newfangled manner; with eagerness for novelty. [Obs.] SirT. More.
NINEPINS: A game played with nine pins, or pieces of wood, set on end, atwhich a wooden ball is bowled to knock them down; bowling.
NEPHELODOMETER: An instrument for reckoning the distances or velocities ofclouds.
NARCOTIC: Having the properties of a narcotic; operating as a narcotic.-- Nar*cot"ic*ness, n.
NITROSALICYLIC: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a nitro derivative ofsalicylic acid, called also anilic acid.
NAPHTHALENIC: Pertaining to , or derived from, naphthalene; -- usedspecifically to designate a yellow crystalline substance, callednaphthalenic acid and also hydroxy quinone, and obtained from certainderivatives of naphthol.
NODAL: Of the nature of, or relating to, a node; as, a nodal point.Nodal line, Nodal point, in a vibrating plate or cord, that line orpoint which remains at rest while the other parts of the body are ina state of vibration.
NICKEL STEEL: A kind of cast steel containing nickel, which greatly increasesits strength. It is used for armor plate, bicycle tubing, propellershafts, etc.
NAPHTHA: The complex mixture of volatile, liquid, inflammablehydrocarbons, occurring naturally, and usually called crudepetroleum, mineral oil, or rock oil. Specifically: That portion ofthe distillate obtained in the refinement of petroleum which isintermediate between the lighter gasoline and the heavier benzine,and has a specific gravity of about 0.7, -- used as a solvent forvarnishes, as a carburetant, illuminant, etc.
NICKLE: The European woodpecker, or yaffle; -- called also nickerpecker.
NOSTALGIA: Homesickness; esp., a severe and sometimes fatal form ofmelancholia, due to homesickness.
NEUVAINES: Prayers offered up for nine successive days.
NORIMON: A Japanese covered litter, carried by men. B. Taylor.
NOSEL: To nurse; to lead or teach; to foster; to nuzzle. [Obs.]If any man use the Scripture . . . to nosel thee in anything save inChrist, he is a false prophet. Tyndale.
NINEHOLES: A game in which nine holes are made in the ground, into which aball is bowled.
NAPOLEON: A French gold coin of twenty francs, or about $3.86.
NONAEROBIOTIC: Capable of living without atmospheric oxygen; anaërobiotic.
NEGATIVELY: The quality or state of being negative.
NAUTILUS: The only existing genus of tetrabranchiate cephalopods. Aboutfour species are found living in the tropical Pacific, but many otherspecies are found fossil. The shell is spiral, symmetrical, andchambered, or divided into several cavities by simple curvedpartitions, which are traversed and connected together by acontinuous and nearly central tube or siphuncle. See Tetrabranchiata.
NIX: One of a class of water spirits, commonly described as of amischievous disposition.The treacherous nixes who entice men to a watery death. Tylor.
NOMARCHY: A province or territorial division of a kingdom, under the ruleof a nomarch, as in modern Greece; a nome.
NOTARY: A public officer who attests or certifies deeds and otherwritings, or copies of them, usually under his official seal, to makethem authentic, especially in foreign countries. His duties chieflyrelate to instruments used in commercial transactions, such asprotests of negotiable paper, ship's papers in cases of loss, damage,etc. He is generally called a notary public.
NITROFORM: A nitro derivative of methane, analogous to chloroform,obtained as a colorless oily or crystalline substance, CH.(NO2)3,quite explosive, and having well-defined acid properties.
NAOS: A term used by modern archæologists instead of cella. SeeCella.
NICOTINISM: The morbid condition produced by the excessive use of tobacco.
NODICAL: Of or pertaining to the nodes; from a node to the same nodeagain; as, the nodical revolutions of the moon. Nodical month. SeeLunar month, under Month.
NOBILIARY: Of or pertaining to the nobility. Fitzed. Hall.
NONRESISTANCE: The principles or practice of a nonresistant; passiveobedience; submission to authority, power, oppression, or violencewithout opposition.
NEGATION: Description or definition by denial, exclusion, or exception;statement of what a thing is not, or has not, from which may beinferred what it is or has.
NESTOR: A genus of parrots with gray heads. of New Zeland and papua,allied to the cockatoos. See Kaka.
NAILERY: A manufactory where nails are made.
NUMMULITES: A genus of extinct Tertiary Foraminifera, having a thin, flat,round shell, containing a large number of small chambers arrangedspirally.
NONYLENIC: Of, pertaining to, related to, or designating, nonylene or itscompounds; as, nonylenic acid.
NORTHWESTERLY: Toward the northwest, or from the northwest.
NEHUSHTAN: A thing of brass; -- the name under which the Israelitesworshiped the brazen serpent made by Moses. 2 Kings xviii. 4.
NUCLEOLE: The nucleus within a nucleus; nucleolus.
NEO-MALTHUSIAN: Designating, or pertaining to, a group of modern economists whohold to the Malthusianism doctrine that permanent betterment of thegeneral standard of living is impossible without decrease ofcompetition by limitation of the number of births. -- Ne`o-Mal*thu"sian, Ne`o-Mal*thu"sian*ism, n.
NEURATION: The arrangement or distribution of nerves, as in the leaves ofa plant or the wings of an insect; nervation.
NUMERATE: To divide off and read according to the rules of numeration;as, to numerate a row of figures.
NONACID: Destitute of acid properties; hence, basic; metallic; positive;-- said of certain atoms and radicals.
NEARHAND: Near; near at hand; closely. [Obs. or Scot.] Bacon.
NITRITE: A salt of nitrous acid. Amyl nitrite, a yellow oily volatileliquid, used in medicine as a depressant and a vaso-dilator. Itsinhalation produces an instantaneous flushing of the face.
NETHINIM: Servants of the priests and Levites in the menial servicesabout the tabernacle and temple.
NORTHWESTERN: Of, pertaining to, or being in, the northwest; in a directiontoward the northwest; coming from the northwest; northwesterly; as, anorthwestern course.
NAVE: The middle or body of a church, extending from the transepts tothe principal entrances, or, if there are no transepts, from thechoir to the principal entrance, but not including the aisles.
NAIVETE: Native simplicity; unaffected plainness or ingenuousness;artlessness.A story which pleases me by its naïveté -- that is, by itsunconscious ingenuousness. De Quincey.
NEUROMA: A tumor developed on, or connected with, a nerve, esp. oneconsisting of new-formed nerve fibers.
NOWED: Knotted; tied in a knot, as a serpent.
NOMBRIL: A point halfway between the fess point and the middle basepoint of an escutcheon; -- called also navel point. See Escutcheon.
NONEXTENSILE: Not extensile; incapable of being stretched.
NOTHING: A cipher; naught. Nothing but, only; no more than. Chaucer.-- To make nothing of. (a) To make no difficulty of; to consider astrifling or important. "We are industrious to preserve our bodiesfrom slavery, but we make nothing of suffering our souls to be slavesto our lusts." Ray. (b) Not to understand; as, I could make nothingof what he said.
NOWHITHER: Not anywhither; in no direction; nowhere. [Archaic] "Thyservant went nowhither." 2 Kings v. 25.
NINCOMPOOP: A fool; a silly or stupid person. [Law]An old ninnyhammer, a dotard, a nincompoop, is the best language shecan afford me. Addison.
NEISHOUT: The mahogany-like wood of the South African tree Pteroxylonutile, the sawdust of which causes violent sneezing (whence thename). Also called sneezewood.
NESTORIANISM: The doctrines of the nestorian Christians, or of Nestorius.
NEODAMODE: In ancient Sparta, one of those Helots who were freed by thestate in reward for military service. Milford.
NERITINA: A genus including numerous species of shells resembling Neritain form. They mostly inhabit brackish water, and are often delicatelytinted.
NOSOGRAPHY: A description or classification of diseases.
NOISE: To sound; to make a noise. Milton.
NECTAREOUS: Of, pertaining to, containing, or resembling nectar; delicious;nectarean. Pope.-- Nec*ta"re*ous*ly, adv.-- Nec*ta"re*ous*ness, n.
NINETEENTH: An interval of two octaves and a fifth.
NYMPHET: A little or young nymph. [Poetic] "The nymphets sportingthere." Drayton.
NULLIFIDIAN: Of no faith; also, not trusting to faith for salvation; --opposed to Ant: solifidian. Feltham.
NEOCRACY: Government by new or inexperienced hands; upstart rule; raw oruntried officials.
NONSTRIATED: Without striations; unstriped; as, nonstriated muscle fibers.
NAUTCH: An entertainment consisting chiefly of dancing by professionaldancing (or Nautch) girls. [India]
NEGLIGEE: An easy, unceremonious attire; undress; also, a kind of easyrobe or dressing gown worn by women.
NAPHTHALIZE: To mingle, saturate, or impregnate, with naphtha.
NECTARY: That part of a blossom which secretes nectar, usually the baseof the corolla or petals; also, the spur of such flowers as thelarkspur and columbine, whether nectariferous or not. See theIllustration of Nasturtium.
NOMADISM: The state of being a nomad.
NECROLOGIST: One who gives an account of deaths.
NOVERCAL: Done or recurring every ninth year.
NIXIE CLERK: A post-office clerk in charge of the nixies.
NUMERARY: Belonging to a certain number; counting as one of a collectionor body.A supernumerary canon, when he obtains a prebend, becomes a numerarycanon. Ayliffe.
NINNYHAMMER: A simpleton; a silly person. [Colloq.] Addison.
NEAPOLITAN: Of of pertaining to Maples in Italy.-- n.
NANKEEN: Trousers made of nankeen. Ld. Lytton. Nankeen bird (Zoöl.), theAustralian night heron (Nycticorax Caledonicus); -- called alsoquaker.
NONCONFORMITY: Neglect or failure of conformity; especially, in England, theneglect or refusal to unite with the established church in its ritesand modes of worship.
NALL: An awl. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.] Tusser.
NATION: A part, or division, of the people of the earth, distinguishedfrom the rest by common descent, language, or institutions; a race; astock.All nations, and kindreds, and people, and tongues. Rev. vii. 9.
NAIAD: A water nymph; one of the lower female divinities, fabled topreside over some body of fresh water, as a lake, river, brook, orfountain.
NASSA: Any species of marine gastropods, of the genera Nassa, Tritia,and other allied genera of the family Nassidæ; a dog whelk. SeeIllust. under Gastropoda.-- nas"soid, a.
NIPPLE: The protuberance through which milk is drawn from the breast ormamma; the mammilla; a teat; a pap.
NECKBAND: A band which goes around the neck; often, the part at the topof a garment.
NIMBLE: Light and quick in motion; moving with ease and celerity;lively; swift.Through the mid seas the nimble pinnace sails. Pope.
NEAR: Adjacent to; close by; not far from; nigh; as, the ship sailednear the land. See the Note under near, a.
NUBIA: A light fabric of wool, worn on the head by women; a cloud.
NIB: The bill or beak of a bird; the neb.
NEATRESS: A woman who takes care of cattle. [R.] Warner.
NOLI-ME-TANGERE: A name formerly applied to several varieties of ulcerouscutaneous diseases, but now restricted to Lupus exedens, anulcerative affection of the nose.
NOTANDUM: A thing to be noted or observed; a notable fact; -- chieflyused in the plural.
NONEXPORTATION: A failure of exportation; a not exporting of commodities.
NOULD: Would not. [Obs.] "By those who nould repent." Fairfax.
NOMINAL: A verb formed from a noun.
NEESING: Sneezing. [Obs.] "By his neesings a light doth shine." Job xli.18.
NEPHOSCOPE: An instrument for observing the clouds and their velocity.
NEGLIGENCE: The quality or state of being negligent; lack of due diligenceor care; omission of duty; habitual neglect; heedlessness.
NITROSACCHARIN: An explosive nitro derivative of certain sugars, analogous tonitroglycerin, gun cotton, etc.
NORIAN: Pertaining to the upper portion of the Laurentian rocks. T. S.Hunt.
NEUTRALIST: A neutral; one who professes or practices neutrality. Milman.
NEVADITE: A grantitoid variety of rhyolite, common in Nevada.
NAUGHTINESS: The quality or state of being naughty; perverseness; badness;wickedness.I know thy pride, and the naughtiness of thine heart. 1 Sam. xvii.28.
NURL: To cut with reeding or fluting on the edge of, as coins, theheads of screws, etc.; to knurl.
NAPHTHOIC: Pertaining to, derived from, or related to, naphthalene; --used specifically to designate any one of a series of carboxylderivatives, called naphthoic acids.
NATURAL: Belonging to, to be taken in, or referred to, some system, inwhich the base is 1; -- said or certain functions or numbers; as,natural numbers, those commencing at 1; natural sines, cosines, etc.,those taken in arcs whose radii are 1.
NUR: A hard knot in wood; also, a hard knob of wood used by boys inplaying hockey.I think I'm as hard as a nur, and as tough as whitleather. W. Howitt.
NEVEN: To name; to mention; to utter. [Obs.]As oft I heard my lord them neven. Chaucer.
NODULAR: Of, pertaining to, or in the form of, a nodule or knot.
NEAPED: Left aground on the height of a spring tide, so that it willnot float till the next spring tide; -- called also beneaped.
NATIVENESS: The quality or state of being native.
NIGH: To draw nigh (to); to approach; to come near. [Obs.] Wyclif(Matt. iii. 2).
NONOBSERVANCE: Neglect or failure to observe or fulfill.
NODULE: A rounded mass or irregular shape; a little knot or lump.
NONCONDUCTOR: A substance which does not conduct, that is, convey ortransmit, heat, electricity, sound, vibration, or the like, or whichtransmits them with difficulty; an insulator; as, wool is anonconductor of heat; glass and dry wood are nonconductors ofelectricity.
NEPHRITIC: A medicine adapted to relieve or cure disease of the kidneys.
NOURISHER: One who, or that which, nourishes. Milton.
NUCLEOPLASMIC: Of or pertaining to nucleoplasm; -- esp. applied to a bodyformed in the developing ovum from the plasma of the nucleus of thegerminal vesicle.
NEURALGIA: A disease, the chief symptom of which is a very acute pain,exacerbating or intermitting, which follows the course of a nervousbranch, extends to its ramifications, and seems therefore to beseated in the nerve. It seems to be independent of any structurallesion. Dunglison.
NOTOPODIUM: The dorsal lobe or branch of a parapodium. See Parapodium.
NURSER: One who nurses; a nurse; one who cherishes or encouragesgrowth.
NOWISE: Not in any manner or degree; in no way; noways.Others whose case is nowise different. Earle.
NOTE: To butt; to push with the horns. [Prov. Eng.]
NEPENTHES: A genus of climbing plants found in India, Malaya, etc., whichhave the leaves prolonged into a kind of stout tendril terminating ina pitcherlike appendage, whence the plants are often called pitcherplants and monkey-cups. There are about thirty species, of which thebest known is Nepenthes distillatoria. See Pitcher plant.
NEUROMERE: A metameric segment of the cerebro-spinal nervous system.
NEMATHECIUM: A peculiar kind of fructification on certain red algæ,consisting of an external mass of filaments at length separating intotetraspores.
NORTHNESS: A tendency in the end of a magnetic needle to point to thenorth. Faraday.
NEWFASHIONED: Made in a new form, or lately come into fashion.
NIGROMANCIEN: A necromancer. [Obs.]These false enchanters or nigromanciens. Chaucer.
NOONSTEAD: The position of the sun at noon. [Obs.] Drayton.
NEWEL: A novelty; a new thing. [Obs.] Spenser.
NONMETAL: Any one of the set of elements which, as contrasted with themetals, possess, produce, or receive, acid rather than basicproperties; a metalloid; as, oxygen, sulphur, and chlorine arenonmetals.
NOSEBAND: That part of the headstall of a bridle which passes over ahorse's nose.
NIOPO: A kind of snuff prepared by the natives of Venezuela from theroasted seeds of a leguminous tree (Piptadenia peregrina), thencecalled niopo tree.
NUNDINATE: To buy and sell at fairs or markets. [Obs.]
NONSLAVEHOLDING: Not possessing or holding slaves; as, a nonslaveholding State.
NINETEEN: Nine and ten; eighteen and one more; one less than twenty; as,nineteen months.
NARDINE: Of or pertaining to nard; having the qualities of nard.
NOTT-HEADED: Having the hair cut close. [Obs.] Chapman.
NAPHTHIDE: A compound of naphthalene or its radical with a metallicelement; as, mercuric naphthide.
NUGACITY: Futility; trifling talk or behavior; drollery. [R.] Dr. H.More.
NIGRIFICATION: The act or process of making black. [R.] Johnson.
NECTOSTEM: That portion of the axis which bears the nectocalyces in theSiphonophora.
NIMBLENESS: The quality of being nimble; lightness and quickness in motion;agility; swiftness.
NECROSIS: Mortification or gangrene of bone, or the death of a bone orportion of a bone in mass, as opposed to its death by moleculardisintegration. See Caries.
NELUMBO: A genus of great water lilies. The North American species isNelumbo lutea, the Asiatic is the sacred lotus, N. speciosa. [Writtenalso Nelumbium.]
NYMPHAEA: A genus of aquatic plants having showy flowers (white, blue,pink, or yellow, often fragrant), including the white water lily andthe Egyptia lotus.
NUMERIC: Any number, proper or improper fraction, or incommensurableratio. The term also includes any imaginary expression like m + nsq.root-1, where m and n are real numerics.
NEGOTIABILITY: The quality of being negotiable or transferable by indorsement.
NAPHTHALENE: A white crystalline aromatic hydrocarbon, C10H8, analogous tobenzene, and obtained by the distillation of certain bituminousmaterials, such as the heavy oil of coal tar. It is the type andbasis of a large number of derivatives among organic compounds.Formerly called also naphthaline. Naphthalene red (Chem.), a dyestuffobtained from certain diazo derivatives of naphthylamine, and calledalso magdala red.-- Naphthalene yellow (Chem.), a yellow dyestuff obtained fromcertain nitro derivatives of naphthol.
NUMERABLE: Capable of being numbered or counted.
NEURAD: Toward the neural side; -- opposed to hæmad.
NAYWARD: The negative side. [R.]Howe'er you lean to the nayward. Shak.
NECROPOLIS: A city of the dead; a name given by the ancients to theircemeteries, and sometimes applied to modern burial places; agraveyard.
NOCTUID: Any one of numerous moths of the family Noctuidæ, orNoctuælitæ, as the cutworm moths, and armyworm moths; -- so calledbecause they fly at night.-- a.
NONPROFICIENT: One who has failed to become proficient.
NEW THOUGHT: Any form of belief in mental healing other than (1) ChristianScience and (2) hypnotism or psychotherapy. Its central principle isaffirmative thought, or suggestion, employed with the conviction thatman produces changes in his health, his finances, and his life by theadoption of a favorable mental attitude. AS a therapeutic doctrine itstands for silent and absent mental treatment, and the theory thatall diseases are mental in origin. As a cult it has its unifying ideathe inculcation of workable optimism in contrast with the "oldthought" of sin, evil, predestination, and pessimistic resignation.The term is essentially synonymous with the term High Thought, usedin England.
NOMARCH: The chief magistrate of a nome or nomarchy.
NEORAMA: A panorama of the interior of a building, seen from within.
NATICA: Any one of numerous species of marine gastropods belonging toNatica, Lunatia, Neverita, and other allied genera (family Naticidæ.)They burrow beneath the sand, or mud, and drill other shells.
NUMERATIVE: Of or pertaining to numeration; as, a numerative system. Eng.Cyc.
NONCONFORMING: Not conforming; declining conformity; especially, notconforming to the established church of a country.
NARDOO: An Australian name for Marsilea Drummondii, a four-leavedcryptogamous plant, sometimes used for food.
NOBLENESS: The quality or state of being noble; greatness; dignity;magnanimity; elevation of mind, character, or station; nobility;grandeur; stateliness.His purposes are full honesty, nobleness, and integrity. Jer. Taylor.
NON EST INVENTUS: The return of a sheriff on a writ, when the defendant is notfound in his county. Bouvier.
NIHILISM: The theories and practices of the Nihilists.
NOODLE: A simpleton; a blockhead; a stupid person; a ninny. [Low]The chuckling grin of noodles. Sydney Smith.
NOILS: Waste and knots of wool removed by the comb; combings.
NUDDLE: To walk quickly with the head bent forward; -- often withalong. [Prov. Eng.]
NOWEL: A kind of hymn, or canticle, of mediæval origin, sung in honorof the Nativity of our Lord; a Christmas carol. Grove.
NOOK: A narrow place formed by an angle in bodies or between bodies;a corner; a recess; a secluded retreat.How couldst thou find this dark, sequestered nook Milton.
NORTHWARD: Toward the north; nearer to the north than to the east or westpoint.
NOROPIANIC: Of, pertaining to, or designating, an acid of the aromaticseries obtained from opianic acid.
NECTARIZE: To mingle or infuse with nectar; to sweeten. [Obs.] Cockeram.
NORIA: A large water wheel, turned by the action of a stream againstits floats, and carrying at its circumference buckets, by which wateris raised and discharged into a trough; used in Arabia, China, andelsewhere for irrigating land; a Persian wheel.
NYSTAGMUS: A rapid involuntary oscillation of the eyeballs.
NON-FEASANCE: An omission or neglect to do something, esp. that which oughtto have been done. Cf. Malfeasance.
NOTAL: Of or pertaining to the back; dorsal.
NODOSARINE: Resembling in form or structure a foraminiferous shell of thegenus Nodosaria.-- n. (Zoöl.)
NATES: The umbones of a bivalve shell.
NANISM: The condition of being abnormally small in stature;dwarfishness; -- opposed to gigantism.
NEURO-EPIDERMAL: Pertaining to, or giving rise to, the central nervous systemand epiderms; as, the neuroepidermal, or epiblastic, layer of theblastoderm.
NEPTUNIUM: A new metallic element, of doubtful genuineness and uncertainindentification, said to exist in certain minerals, as columbite.Hermann.
NOCTUARY: A record of what passes in the night; a nightly journal; --distinguished from diary. [R.] Addison.
NEWNESS: The quality or state of being new; as, the newness of a system;the newness of a scene; newness of life.
NIPPLEWORT: A yellow-flowered composite herb (Lampsana communis), formerlyused as an external application to the nipples of women; -- calledalso dock-cress.
NECESSARILY: In a necessary manner; by necessity; unavoidably;indispensably.
NOTED: Well known by reputation or report; eminent; celebrated; as, anoted author, or traveler.-- Not"ed*ly, adv.-- Not"ed*ness, n.
NAIVE: Having native or unaffected simplicity; ingenuous; artless;frank; as, naïve manners; a naïve person; naïve and unsophisticatedremarks.
NECROPSY: A post-mortem examination or inspection; an autopsy. SeeAutopsy.
NICOTINIC: Pertaining to, or derived from, nicotine; nicotic; -- usedspecifically to designate an acid related to pyridine, obtained bythe oxidation of nicotine, and called nicotinic acid.
NAB: The cock of a gunlock. Knight.
NICKELODEON: A place of entertainment, as for moving picture exhibition,charging a fee or admission price of five cents. [U. S.]
NONMEMBER: One who is not a member.
NACRE: A pearly substance which lines the interior of many shells, andis most perfect in the mother-of-pearl. [Written also nacker andnaker.] See Pearl, and Mother-of-pearl.
NONPLANE: Not lying in one plane; -- said of certain curves.
NEOGAEAN: Of or pertaining to the New World, or Western Hemisphere.
NARRAGANSETTS: A tribe of Indians who formerly inhabited the shores ofNarragansett Bay.
NEMATOCERA: A suborder of dipterous insects, having long antennæ, as themosquito, gnat, and crane fly; -- called also Nemocera.
NEHILOTH: A term supposed to mean, perforated wind instruments of music,as pipes or flutes. Ps. v. (heading).
NORFOLK SPANIEL: One of a breed of field spaniels similar to the clumbers, butshorter in body and of a liver-and-white or black-and-white color.
NONREGARDANCE: Want of due regard; disregard; slight. [Obs.] Shak.
NEUTRALITY: The quality or state of being neutral. See Neutral, a., 4.
NEMATO-: . A combining from Gr. nhema, nhematos, a thread.
NEROLI: An essential oil obtained by distillation from the flowers ofthe orange. It has a strong odor, and is used in perfumery, etc.Neroli camphor (Chem.), a white crystalline waxy substance, tastelessand odorless, obtained from beroli oil; -- called also auradin.
NIDIFICATE: To make a nest.Where are the fishes which nidificated in trees Lowell.
NEUROTIC: Any toxic agent whose action is mainly directed to the greatnerve centers.
NIVOSE: The fourth month of the French republican calendar [1792-1806].It commenced December 21, and ended January 19. See VendÉmiaire.
NATTER: To find fault; to be peevish. [Prov. Eng. or Scot.]
NATIVE: Any of the live stock found in a region, as distinguished fromsuch as belong to pure and distinct imported breeds. [U.S.]
NOTCHBOARD: The board which receives the ends of the steps in a staircase.
NEUROGLIA: The delicate connective tissue framework which supports thenervous matter and blood vessels of the brain and spinal cord.
NAP-TAKING: A taking by surprise; an unexpected onset or attack. Carew.
NEUROKERATIN: A substance, resembling keratin, present in nerve tissue, as inthe sheath of the axis cylinder of medullated nerve fibers. Likekeratin it resists the action of most chemical agents, and bydecomposition with sulphuric acid yields leucin and tyrosin.
NAVARRESE: Of or pertaining to Navarre.-- n. sing. & pl.
NICOLAITAN: One of certain corrupt persons in the early church at Ephesus,who are censured in rev. ii. 6, 15.
NARD: An East Indian plant (Nardostachys Jatamansi) of the Valerianfamily, used from remote ages in Oriental perfumery.
NONCONDENSIBLE: Not condensible; incapable of being liquefied; -- said ofgases.
NEPTUNE: The son of Saturn and Ops, the god of the waters, especially ofthe sea. He is represented as bearing a trident for a scepter.
NEEDLEWOMAN: A woman who does needlework; a seamstress.
NOTODONTIAN: Any one of several species of bombycid moths belonging toNotodonta, Nerice, and allied genera. The caterpillar of these mothshas a hump, or spine, on its back.
NATURISM: The belief or doctrine that attributes everything to nature asa sanative agent.
NECKLACE: A rope or chain fitted around the masthead to hold hangingblocks for jibs and stays.
NATURAL STEEL: Steel made by the direct refining of cast iron in a finery, or,as wootz, by a direct process from the ore.
NEONOMIANISM: The doctrines or belief of the neonomians.
NIAGARA PERIOD: A subdivision or the American Upper Silurian system, embracingthe Medina, Clinton, and Niagara epoch. The rocks of the Niagaraepoch, mostly limestones, are extensively distributed, and at NiagaraFalls consist of about eighty feet of shale supporting a greaterthickness of limestone, which is gradually undermined by the removalof the shale. See Chart of Geology.
NONDESCRIPT: Not hitherto described; novel; hence, odd; abnormal;unclassifiable.
NEGLECTION: The state of being negligent; negligence. [Obs.] Shak.
NETTLING: Stinging; irritating. Nettling cell (Zoöl.), a lasso cell. Seeunder Lasso.
NEXUS: Connection; tie.Man is doubtless one by some subtile nexus ... extending from thenew-born infant to the superannuated dotard. De Quincey.
NEOZOIC: More recent than the Paleozoic, -- that is, including theMesozoic and Cenozoic.
NUMPS: A dolt; a blockhead. [Obs.] Bp. Parker.
NAVIGEROUS: Bearing ships; capable of floating vessels. [R.] Blount.
NUTLET: A small nut; also, the stone of a drupe.
NEUROGRAPHY: A description of the nerves. Dunglison.
NEBULE: A little cloud; a cloud. [Obs.]O light without nebule. Old Ballad.
NEURULA: An embryo or certain invertebrates in the stage when theprimitive band is first developed.
NEOCLASSIC ARCHITECTURE: All that architecture which, since the beginning of the ItalianRenaissance, about 1420, has been designed with deliberate imitationof Greco-Roman buildings.
NOYOUS: Annoying; disagreeable. [Obs.]Watch the noyous night, and wait for Spenser.
NOETIAN: One of the followers of Noetus, who lived in the third century.He denied the distinct personality of the Father, Son, and HolyGhost.
NECESSITIED: In a state of want; necessitous. [Obs.] Shak.
NITTER: The horselouse; an insect that deposits nits on horses.
NUMERATOR: The term in a fraction which indicates the number of fractionalunits that are taken.
NITRUM: Niter. Nitrum flammans Etym: [L., flaming niter] (Old Chem.),ammonium nitrate; -- probably so called because it deflagerates whensuddenly heated.
NERVIMOTION: The movement caused in the sensory organs by external agentsand transmitted to the muscles by the nerves. Dunglison.
NOVATION: A substitution of a new debt for an old one; also, theremodeling of an old obligation.
NUDE: Naked; without consideration; void; as, a nude contract. SeeNudum pactum. Blackstone. The nude, the undraped human figure in art.-- Nude"ly, adv.- Nude"ness, n.
NOTORHIZAL: Having the radicle of the embryo lying against the back of oneof the cotyledons; incumbent.
NAPHTHENE: A peculiar hydrocarbon occuring as an ingredient of Caucasianpetroleum.
NOMAD: One of a race or tribe that has no fixed location, but wandersfrom place to place in search of pasture or game.
NICK: An evil spirit of the waters. Old Nick, the evil one; thedevil. [Colloq.]
NONCE: The one or single occasion; the present call or purpose; --chiefly used in the phrase for the nonce.The miller was a stout carl for the nones. Chaucer.And that he calls for drink, I 'll have prepared him A chalice forthe nonce. Shak.Nonce word, "a word apparently employed only for the nonce". Murray(New English Dict. ).
NESH: Soft; tender; delicate. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]
NEF: The nave of a church. Addison.
NOCAKE: Indian corn parched, and beaten to powder, -- used for food bythe Northern American Indians.
NAUTILOID: Like or pertaining to the nautilus; shaped like a nautilusshell.-- n.
NUMMULATION: The arrangement of the red blood corpuscles in rouleaux, likepiles of coins, as when a drop of human blood is examined under themicroscope.
NYULA: A species of ichneumon (Herpestes nyula). Its fur isbeautifully variegated by closely set zigzag markings.
NICKEL: A bright silver-white metallic element. It is of the irongroup, and is hard, malleable, and ductile. It occurs combined withsulphur in millerite, with arsenic in the mineral niccolite, and witharsenic and sulphur in nickel glance. Symbol Ni. Atomic weight 58.6.
NAMAYCUSH: A large North American lake trout (Salvelinus namaycush). It isusually spotted with red, and sometimes weighs over forty pounds.Called also Mackinaw trout, lake trout, lake salmon, salmon trout,togue, and tuladi.
NONATTENDANCE: A failure to attend; omission of attendance; nonappearance.
NIGHTMAN: One whose business is emptying privies by night.
NEGRO: A black man; especially, one of a race of black or very darkpersons who inhabit the greater part of tropical Africa, and aredistinguished by crisped or curly hair, flat noses, and thickprotruding lips; also, any black person of unmixed African blood,wherever found.
NEOGRAPHY: A new method or system of writing.
NAPE: The back part of the neck. Spenser.
NEOSSINE: The substance constituting the edible bird's nest.
NORTHWESTER: A storm or gale from the northwest; a strong northwest wind.
NEURISM: Nerve force. See Vital force, under Vital.
NEGOTIABLE: Capable of being negotiated; transferable by assigment orindorsement to another person; as, a negotiable note or bill ofexchange. Negotiable paper, any commercial paper transferable by saleor delivery and indorsement, as bills of exchange, drafts, checks,and promissory notes.
NONCOMMISSIONED: Not having a commission. Noncommissioned officer (Mil.), asubordinate officer not appointed by a commission from the chiefexecutive or supreme authority of the State; but by the Secretary ofWar or by the commanding officer of the regiment.
NAUTICAL: Of or pertaining to seamen, to the art of navigation, or toships; as, nautical skill.
NERVIMOTOR: Any agent capable of causing nervimotion. Dunglison.
NEOCLASSIC: Belonging to, or designating, the modern revival of classical,esp. Greco-Roman, taste and manner of work in architecture, etc.
NONDELIVERY: A neglect or failure of delivery; omission of delivery.
NUGATION: The act or practice of trifling. [R.] Bacon.
NITTINGS: The refuse of good ore. Raymond.
NECROTIC: Affected with necrosis; as, necrotic tissue; characterized by,or producing, necrosis; as, a necrotic process.
NOMINALIST: One of a sect of philosophers in the Middle Ages, who adoptedthe opinion of Roscelin, that general conceptions, or universals,exist in name only. Reid.
NITRIFEROUS: Bearing niter; yielding, or containing, niter.
NORTHERLY: Of or pertaining to the north; toward the north, or from thenorth; northern.
NONONE: Any one of several metameric unsaturated hydrocarbons (C9H14)of the valylene series.
NEATHERD: A person who has the care of neat cattle; a cowherd. Dryden.
NECESSARIANISM: The doctrine of philosophical necessity; necessitarianism.Hixley.
NONPREPARATION: Neglect or failure to prepare; want of preparation.
NASOTURBINAL: Connected with, or near, both the turbinal and the nasal bones;as, the nasalturbinal bone, made up of the uppermost lammelæ of theethmoturbinal, and sometimes united with the nasal.-- n.
NESTORIAN: An adherent of Nestorius, patriarch of Constantinople to thefifth century, who has condemned as a heretic for maintaining thatthe divine and the human natures were not merged into one nature inChrist (who was God in man), and, hence, that it was improper to callMary the mother of Christ; also, one of the sect established by thefollowers of Nestorius in Persia, india, and other Orientalcountries, and still in existence. opposed to Ant: Eutychian.
NIPPERS: A device with fingers or jaws for seizing an object and holdingor conveying it; as, in a printing press, a clasp for catching asheet and conveying it to the form.
NEGOTIOSITY: The state of being busy; multitude of business. [Obs.]
NOVENE: Relating to, or dependent on, the number nine; novenary. [R.]The triple and novene division ran throughout. Milman.
NEUROTOMIST: One who skilled in or practices neurotomy.
NOCTIVAGATION: A roving or going about in the night. Gayton.
NOBBY: Stylish; modish; elegant; showy; aristocratic; fashionable.[Slang]
NICKELIC: Pertaining to, or containing, nickel; specifically, designatingcompounds in which, as contrasted with the nickelous compounds, themetal has a higher valence; as nickelic oxide.
NUCLEOIDIOPLASMA: Hyaline plasma contained in the nucleus of vegetable cells.
NEGLIGIBLE: That may neglicted, disregarded, or left out of consideration.Within very negligible limits of error. Sir J. Herschel.
NOTWITHSTANDING: Without prevention, or obstruction from or by; in spite of.We gentil women bee Loth to displease any wight, Notwithstanding ourgreat right. Chaucer's Dream.Those on whom Christ bestowed miraculous cures were so transportedthat their gratitude made them, notwithstanding his prohibition,proclaim the wonders he had done. Dr. H. More.
NIGRITUDE: Blackness; the state of being black. Lamb.
NORTHEASTER: A storm, strong wind, or gale, coming from the northeast.
NUDIBRANCH: Of or pertaining to the Nudibranchiata.-- n.
NOWADAYS: In these days; at the present time.What men of spirit, nowadays, Come to give sober judgment of newplays Garrick.
NORMALIZATION: Reduction to a standard or normal state.
NICOTIANINE: A white waxy substance having a hot, bitter taste, extractedfrom tobacco leaves and called also tobacco camphor.
NAUGHT: In no degree; not at all. Chaucer.To wealth or sovereign power he naught applied. Fairfax.
NEEDINESS: The state or quality of being needy; want; poverty; indigence.
NYS: Is not. See Nis. Chaucer. Spenser.
NEGRITOS: A degraded Papuan race, inhabiting Luzon and some of the othereast Indian Islands. They resemble negroes, but are smaller in size.They are mostly nomads.
NEOPLATONISM: A pantheistic eclectic school of philosophy, of which Plotinuswas the chief (A. D. 205-270), and which sought to reconcile thePlatonic and Aristotelian systems with Oriental theosophy. It tendedto mysticism and theurgy, and was the last product of Greekphilosophy.
