NONCONSTAT: It does not appear; it is not plain or clear; it does notfollow.
NUCLEUS: The body or the head of a comet.
NEURILITY: The special properties and functions of the nerves; thatcapacity for transmitting a stimulus which belongs to nerves. G. H.Lewes.
NOONING: A rest at noon; a repast at noon.
NAUSEATE: To become squeamish; to feel nausea; to turn away with disgust.
NITROMAGNESITE: Nitrate of magnesium, a saline efflorescence closely resemblingnitrate of calcium.
NARCOSIS: Privation of sense or consciousness, due to a narcotic.
NONSENSITIVE: Not sensitive; wanting sense or perception; not easilyaffected.
NULLIPORE: A name for certain crustaceous marine algæ which secretecarbonate of lime on their surface, and were formerly thought to beof animal nature. They are now considered corallines of the generaMelobesia and Lithothamnion.
NOG: A treenail to fasten the shores.
NIGROSINE: A dark blue dyestuff, of the induline group; -- called alsoazodiphenyl blue.
NOULE: The top of the head; the head or noll. [Obs.] Spenser.
NAVEW: A kind of small turnip, a variety of Brassica campestris. SeeBrassica. [Writen also naphew.]
NEWFANGLENESS: Newfangledness. [Obs.] Chaucer.Proud newfangleness in their apparel. Robynson (More's Utopia).
NAVAL: Having to do with shipping; of or pertaining to ships or anavy; consisting of ships; as, naval forces, successes, stores, etc.
NONDO: A coarse umbelliferous plant (Ligusticum actæifolium) with alarge aromatic root. It is found chiefly in the Alleghany region.Also called Angelico.
NUMMULITE: A fossil of the genus Nummulites and allied genera.
NONMETALLIC: Resembling, or possessing the properties of, a nonmetal ormetalloid; as, sulphur is a nonmetallic element.
NIT: The egg of a louse or other small insect. Nit grass (Bot.), apretty annual European grass (Gastridium lendigerum), with smallspikelets somewhat resembling a nit. It is also found in Californiaand Chili.
NYMPHOMANIA: Morbid and uncontrollable sexual desire in women, constitutinga true disease.
NAZARITISM: The vow and practice of a Nazarite.
NEGOTIATOR: One who negotiates; a person who treats with others, either asprincipal or agent, in respect to purchase and sale, or publiccompacts.
NEGOTIOUSNESS: The state of being busily occupied; activity. [R.] D. Rogers.
NONAPPOINTMENT: Neglect of making appointment; failure to receive anappointment.
NAPUS: A kind of turnip. See Navew.
NIGHTTIME: The time from dusk to dawn; -- opposed to Ant: daytime.
NOSTOC: A genus of algæ. The plants are composed of moniliform cellsimbedded in a gelatinous substance.
NEWFANGLEDNESS: Affectation of, or fondness for, novelty; vain or affectedfashion or form.
NOSTALGIC: Of or pertaining to nostalgia; affected with nostalgia.
NOVEL: Of recent origin or introduction; not ancient; new; hence, outof the ordinary course; unusual; strange; surprising.
NECROSED: Affected by necrosis; dead; as, a necrosed bone. Dunglison.
NICHED: Placed in a niche. "Those niched shapes of noble mold."Tennyson.
NARRATOR: One who narrates; one who relates a series of events ortransactions.
NECKWEAR: A collective term for cravats, collars, etc. [Colloq. or tradename]
NIGHTSHADE: A common name of many species of the genus Solanum, given esp.to the Solanum nigrum, or black nightshade, a low, branching weedwith small white flowers and black berries reputed to be poisonous.Deadly nightshade. Same as Belladonna (a).-- Enchanter's nightshade. See under Enchanter.-- Stinking nightshade. See Henbane.-- Three-leaved nightshade. See Trillium.
NITROMURIATIC: Of, pertaining to, or composed of, nitric acid and muriaticacid; nitrohydrochloric. See Nitrohydrochloric.
NAZARENE: One of a sect of Judaizing Christians in the first and secondcenturies, who observed the laws of Moses, and held to certainheresies.
NEBULY: A line or a direction composed of successive short curves orwaves supposed to resembe a cloud. See NÉbulÉ
NORTH: Lying toward the north; situated at the north, or in a northerndirection from the point of observation or reckoning; proceedingtoward the north, or coming from the north. North following. SeeFollowing, a., 2.-- North pole, that point in the heavens, or on the earth, ninetydegrees from the equator toward the north.-- North preceding. See Following, a., 2.-- North star, the star toward which the north pole of the earthvery nearly points, and which accordingly seems fixed and immovablein the sky. The star a (alpha) of the Little Bear, is our presentnorth star, being distant from the pole about 1º 25', and from yearto year approaching slowly nearer to it. It is called also Cynosura,polestar, and by astronomers, Polaris.
NEIGHBORLINESS: The quality or state of being neighborly.
NOSOCOMIAL: Of or pertaining to a hospital; as, nosocomial atmosphere.Dunglison.
NINE-BARK: A white-flowered rosaceous shrub (Neillia, or Spiræa,opulifolia), common in the Northern United States. The bark separatesinto many thin layers, whence the name.
NUMSKULL: A dunce; a dolt; a stupid fellow. [Colloq.]They have talked like numskulls. Arbuthnot.
NEUTRALIZE: To render inert or imperceptible the peculiar affinities of, asa chemical substance; to destroy the effect of; as, to neutralize anacid with a base.
NEBULIZE: To reduce (as a liquid) to a fine spray or vapor; to atomize.
NIDGERY: A trifle; a piece of foolery. [Obs.] Skinner.
NAYT: To refuse; to deny. [Obs.] "He shall not nayt ne deny his sin."Chaucer.
NONESUCH: A person or thing of a sort that there is no other such;something extraordinary; a thing that has not its equal. It is givenas a name to various objects, as to a choice variety of apple, aspecies of medic (Medicago lupulina), a variety of pottery clay, etc.
NIMBLY: In a nimble manner; with agility; with light, quick motion.
NONTRONITE: A greenish yellow or green mineral, consisting chiefly of thehydrous silicate of iron.
NAZARITIC: Of or pertaining to a Nazarite, or to Nazarites.
NULLED: Turned so as to resemble nulls. Nulled work (Cabinetwork),ornamental turned work resembling nulls or beads strung on a rod.
NAPHTHYL: A hydrocarbon radical regarded as the essential residue ofnaphthalene.
NITRIC: Of, pertaining to, or containing, nitrogen; specifically,designating any one of those compounds in which, as contrasted withnitrous compounds, the element has a higher valence; as, nitricoxide; nitric acid. Nitric acid, a colorless or yellowish liquidobtained by distilling a nitrate with sulphuric acid. It ispowerfully corrosive, being a strong acid, and in decomposition astrong oxidizer.-- Nitric anhydride, a white crystalline oxide of nitrogen (N2O5),called nitric pentoxide, and regarded as the anhydride of nitricacid.-- Nitric oxide, a colorless poisous gas (NO) obtained by treatingnitric acid with copper. On contact with the air or with oxygen, itbecomes reddish brown from the formation of nitric dioxide orperoxide.
NEGINOTH: Stringed instruments. Dr. W. Smith.To the chief musician on Neginoth. Ps. iv. 9heading).
NEURASTHENIA: A condition of nervous debility supposed to be dependent uponimpairment in the functions of the spinal cord.
NYCTHEMERON: The natural day and night, or space of twenty-four hours.
NATURED: Having (such) a nature, temper, or disposition; disposed; --used in composition; as, good-natured, ill-natured, etc.
NONTENURE: A plea of a defendant that he did not hold the land, asaffirmed.
NULLIFICATION: The act of nullifying; a rendering void and of no effect, or ofno legal effect. Right of nullification (U. S. Hist.), the rightclaimed in behalf of a State to nullify or make void, by itssovereign act or decree, an enactment of the general government whichit deems unconstitutional.
NONSUBMISSION: Want of submission; failure or refusal to submit.
NITRILE: Any one of a series of cyanogen compounds; particularly, one ofthose cyanides of alcohol radicals which, by boiling with acids oralkalies, produce a carboxyl acid, with the elimination of thenitrogen as ammonia.
NACREOUS: Consisting of, or resembling, nacre; pearly.
NIDING: A coward; a dastard; -- a term of utmost opprobrium. [Obs.]He is worthy to be called a niding. Howell.
NIMBIFEROUS: Serving to bring clouds or stormy weather.
NITRIFY: To combine or impregnate with nitrogen; to convert, byoxidation, into nitrous or nitric acid; to subject to, or produce by,nitrification.
NAIL: the horny scale of plate of epidermis at the end of the fingersand toes of man and many apes.His nayles like a briddes claws were. Chaucer.
NEOTERIZE: To innovate; to coin or introduce new words.Freely as we of the nineteenth century neoterize. fized. Hall.
NAVAJOES: A tribe of Indians inhabiting New Mexico and Arizona, allied tothe Apaches. They are now largely engaged in agriculture.
NAPHA WATER: A perfume distilled from orange flowers.
NECESSARY: Such things, in respect to infants, lunatics, and marriedwomen, as are requisite for support suitable to station.
NATIONALIST: One who advocates national unity and independence; one of aparty favoring Irish independence.
NAPE-CREST: An African bird of the genus Schizorhis, related to theplantain eaters.
NERVINE: Having the quality of acting upon or affecting the nerves;quieting nervous excitement.-- n.
NERO-ANTICO: A beautiful black marble found in fragments among Roman ruins,and usually thought to have come from ancient Laconia.
NAP: A short sleep; a doze; a siesta. Cowper.
NECESSARIAN: An advocate of the doctrine of philosophical necessity; anacessitarian.
NEBULOUS: Of, pertaining to, or having the appearance of, a nebula;nebular; cloudlike.-- Neb"u*lous*ly, adv.-- Neb"u*lous*ness, n.
NEGATIVE: Asserting absence of connection between a subject and apredicate; as, a negative proposition.
NIMIETY: State of being in excess. [R.]There is a nimiety, a too-muchess, in all Germans. Coleridge.
NECTAR: The drink of the gods (as ambrosia was their food); hence, anydelicious or inspiring beverage.
NIBBLE: To bite by little at a time; to seize gently with the mouth; toeat slowly or in small bits.Thy turfy mountains, where live nibbling sheep. Shak.
NITRANILIC: Of, pertaining to, or designating, a complex organic acidproduced as a white crystalline substance by the action of nitrousacid on hydroquinone.
NAPPING: A sheet of partially felted fur before it is united to the hatbody. Knight.
NUDATION: The act of stripping, or making bare or naked.
NEUROPATHY: An affection of the nervous system or of a nerve.
NARINE: Of or belonging to the nostrils.
NEWSMONGER: One who deals in news; one who is active in hearing and tellingnews.
NUMIDIAN: Of or pertaining to ancient Numidia in Northern Africa.Numidian crane. (Zoöl.) See Demoiselle, 2.
NEURENTERIC: Of or pertaining to both the neuron and the enteron; as, theneurenteric canal, which, in embroys of many vertebrates, connectsthe medullary tube and the primitive intestine. See Illust. ofEctoderm.
NICCOLITE: A mineral of a copper-red color and metallic luster; anarsenide of nickel; -- called also coppernickel, kupfernickel.
NEMATOGENE: One of the dimorphic forms of the species of Dicyemata, whichproduced vermiform embryos; -- opposed to Ant: rhombogene.
NAVIGATOR: One who navigates or sails; esp., one who direct the course ofa ship, or one who is skillful in the art of navigation; also, a bookwhich teaches the art of navigation; as, Bowditch's Navigator.
NORTHERLINESS: The quality or state of being northerly; direction toward thenorth.
NEEDLE: One of the needle-shaped secondary leaves of pine trees. SeePinus.
NYMPHOLEPTIC: Under the influence of nympholepsy; ecstatic; frenzied.[Poetic]
NIDAMENTAL: of, pertaining to, or baring, eggs or egg capsules; as, thenidament capsules of certain gastropods; nidamental glands. SeeIllust. of Dibranchiata.
NE TEMERE: A decree of the Congregation of the Council declaring invalid[so far as the laws of the Roman Catholic Church are concerned] anymarriage of a Roman Catholic, or of a person who has ever been aRoman Catholic, if not contracted before a duty qualified priest (orthe bishop of the diocese) and at least two witnesses. The decree wasissued Aug. 2, 1907, and took effect on Easter Apr. 19, 1908. Thedecree by its terms does not affect mixed marriages (those betweenRoman Catholics and persons of another faith) in Germany.
NONELECT: A person or persons not elected, or chosen, to salvation.
NECROTOMY: The dissection of dead bodies; also, excision of necrosed bone.--Nec`ro*tom"ic (#), a. --Nec*rot"o*mist (#), n.
NUMMULITIC: Of, like, composed of, containing, nummulites; as, nummuliticbeds.
NEIGHBORSHIP: The state of being neighbors. [R.] J. Bailie.
NECROPHORE: Any one of numerous species of beetles of the genus Necrophorusand allied genera; -- called also burying beetle, carrion beetle,sexton beetle.
NAPOLEONIST: A supporter of the dynasty of the Napoleons.
NONACCEPTANCE: A neglect or refusal to accept.
NONPROFESSIONAL: Not belonging to a profession; not done by, or proceeding from,professional men; contrary to professional usage.
NASALLY: In a nasal manner; by the nose.
NANDINE: An African carnivore (Nandinia binotata), allied to the civets.It is spotted with black.
NORIUM: A supposed metal alleged to have been discovered in zircon.
NATTERJACK: A European toad (Bufo calamita), having a yellow line along itsback.
NOCTURNE: A night piece, or serenade. The name is now used for a certaingraceful and expressive form of instrumental composition, as thenocturne for orchestra in Mendelsohn's "Midsummer-Night's Dream"music.
NECROMANCER: One who practices necromancy; a sorcerer; a wizard.
NATIONALNESS: The quality or state of being national; nationality. Johnson.
NIELLIST: One who practices the style of ornamentation called niello.
NESSLERIZE: To treat or test, as a liquid, with a solution of mercuriciodide in potassium iodide and potassium hydroxide, which is calledNessler's solution or Nessler's test, and is used to detect thepresence of ammonia.
NITROL: Any one of a series of hydrocarbons containing the nitro andthe nitroso or isonitroso group united to the same carbon atom.
NONRENDITION: Neglect of rendition; the not rendering what is due.The nonrendition of a service which is due. S. E. Dwight.
NON ASSUMPSIT: The general plea or denial in an action of assumpsit.
NAUGHTY: Orig., a method of therapeutic treatment administered, esp. forchronic diseases of the curculatory system, at Bad Nauheim, Germany,by G. Schott, consisting in baths in the natural mineral waters ofthat place, which are charged with carbonic acid, and the use of agraduated course of rest, physical exercises, massage, etc.; hence,any similar treatment using waters artificially charged with theessential ingredients of the natural mineral waters of Bad Nauheim.Hence, Nauheim bath, etc.
NEB: The nose; the snout; the mouth; the beak of a bird; a nib, asof a pen. [Also written nib.] Shak.
NOWHERE: Not anywhere; not in any place or state; as, the book isnowhere to be found.
NOT: Wot not; know not; knows not. [Obs.] Chaucer.
NEUTRALLY: In a neutral manner; without taking part with either side;indifferently.
NIDOR: Scent or savor of meat or food, cooked or cooking. [Obs.] Jer.Taylor.
NEATNESS: The state or quality of being neat.
NIGHTLY: Of or pertaining to the night, or to every night; happening ordone by night, or every night; as, nightly shades; he kept nightlyvigils.
NONINFLECTIONAL: Not admitting of, or characterized by, inflection.
NON-EGO: The union of being and relation as distinguished from, andcontrasted with, the ego. See Ego.
NONAGON: A figure or polygon having nine sides and nine angles.
NERVED: Having nerves, or simple and parallel ribs or veins. Gray.
NEPAULESE: Of or pertaining to Nepaul, a kingdom in Northern Hindostan.-- n. sing. & pl.
NUTRITIAL: Pertaining to, or connected with, nutrition; nutritious. [Obs.]Chapman.
NASALIZATION: The act of nasalizing, or the state of being nasalized.
NONES: The fifth day of the months January, February, April, June,August, September, November, and December, and the seventh day ofMarch, May, July, and October. The nones were nine days before theides, reckoning inclusively, according to the Roman method.
NOVENNIAL: Done or recurring every ninth year.
NUTATION: A very small libratory motion of the earth's axis, by which itsinclination to the plane of the ecliptic is constantly varying by asmall amount.
NATURITY: The quality or state of being produced by nature. [Obs.] Sir T.Browne.
NEOTERIC: One of modern times; a modern.
NYMPHAL: Of or pertaining to a nymph or nymphs; nymphean.
NONDA: The edible plumlike fruit of the Australian tree, ParinariumNonda.
NOVICE: One who enters a religious house, whether of monks or nuns, asa probationist. Shipley.No poore cloisterer, nor no novys. Chaucer.
NIAS: A young hawk; an eyas; hence, an unsophisticated person. [Obs.]
NONSUIT: A neglect or failure by the plaintiff to follow up his suit; astopping of the suit; a renunciation or withdrawal of the cause bythe plaintiff, either because he is satisfied that he can not supportit, or upon the judge's expressing his opinion. A compulsory nonsuitis a nonsuit ordered by the court on the ground that the plaintiff onhis own showing has not made out his case.
NICHE: A cavity, hollow, or recess, generally within the thickness ofa wall, for a statue, bust, or other erect ornament. hence, anysimilar position, literal or figurative.Images defended from the injuries of the weather by niches of stonewherein they are placed. Evelun.
NAYAUR: A specied of wild sheep (Ovis Hodgsonii), native of Nepaul andThibet. It has a dorsal mane and a white ruff beneath the neck.
NOBLEMAN: One of the nobility; a noble; a peer; one who enjoys rank abovea commoner, either by virtue of birth, by office, or by patent.
NECTARIAL: Of or pertaining to the nectary of a plant.
NIGHT TERRORS: A sudden awkening associated with a sensation of terror,occurring in children, esp. those of unstable nervous constitution.
NAKED: Without pubescence; as, a naked leaf or stem; bare, or notcovered by the customary parts, as a flower without a perianth, astem without leaves, seeds without a pericarp, buds without budscales.
NEWSROOM: A room where news is collected and disseminated, or periodicalssold; a reading room supplied with newspapers, magazines, etc.
NEWT: Any one of several species of small aquatic salamanders. Thecommon British species are the crested newt (Triton cristatus) andthe smooth newt (Lophinus punctatus). In America, Diemictylusviridescens is one of the most abundant species.
NONMORAL: Not moral nor immoral; having no connection with morals; not inthe sphere of morals or ethics; not ethical.
NEPTUNIAN: Formed by water or aqueous solution; as, Neptunian rocks.Neptunian races (Ethnol.), the Malay and Polynesian races.-- Neptunian theory (Geol.), the theory of Werner, which referredthe formation of all rocks and strata to the agency of water; --opposed to the Plutonic theory.
NASCENCY: State of being nascent; birth; beginning; origin.
NATROLITE: A zeolite occuring in groups of glassy acicular crystals, andin masses which often have a radiated structure. It is a hydroussilicate of alumina and soda.
NIPPITATE: Peculiary strong and good; -- said of ale or liquor. [Old Cant]'T will make a cup of wine taste nippitate. Chapman.
NIMBUS: A circle, or disk, or any indication of radiant light aroundthe heads of divinities, saints, and sovereigns, upon medals,pictures, etc.; a halo. See Aureola, and Glory, n., 5.
NIVEOUS: Snowy; resembling snow; partaking of the qualities of snow. SirT. Browne.
NULLAH: A water course, esp. a dry one; a gully; a gorge; -- orig. anEast Indian term.  E. Arnold.
NOCTULE: A large European bat (Vespertilio, or Noctulina, altivolans).
NECESSITY: The negation of freedom in voluntary action; the subjection ofall phenomena, whether material or spiritual, to inevitablecausation; necessitarianism. Of necessity, by necessary consequence;by compulsion, or irresistible power; perforce.
NEVERTHELESS: Not the less; notwithstanding; in spite of that; yet.No chastening for the present seemeth to be joyous, but grievous;nevertheless, afterward it yieldeth the peaceable fruit ofrighteousness. Heb. xii. 11.
NONPLUS: A state or condition which daffles reason or confoundsjudgment; insuperable difficalty; inability to proceed or decide;puzzle; quandary.Both of them are a perfect nonplus and baffle to all humanunderstanding. South.
NODDER: One who nods; a drowsy person.
NILOTIC: Of or pertaining to the river Nile; as, the Nilotic crocodile.
NONTERM: A vacation between two terms of a court.
NOMINATIVELY: In the manner of a nominative; as a nominative.
NUZZLE: To nestle; to house, as in a nest.
NONOIC: Pertaining to, derived from, or resembling, nonane; as, nonoicacid, which is also called pelargonic acid. Cf. Pelargonic.
NEXT: In the time, place, or order nearest or immediately suceeding;as, this man follows next.
NAUPLIUS: A crustacean larva having three pairs of locomotive organs(corresponding to the antennules, antennæ, and mandibles), a medianeye, and little or no segmentation of the body.
NAVIGATE: To joirney by water; to go in a vessel or ship; to perform theduties of a navigator; to use the waters as a highway or channel forcommerce or communication; to sail.The Phenicians navigated to the extremities of the Western Ocean.Arbuthnot.
NETTLE: A plant of the genus Urtica, covered with minute sharp hairscontaining a poison that produces a stinging sensation. Urticagracitis is common in the Northern, and U. chamædryoides in theSouthern, United States. the common European species, U. urens and U.dioica, are also found in the Eastern united States. U. pilulifera isthe Roman nettle of England.
NOUMENON: The of itself unknown and unknowable rational object, or thingin itself, which is distinguished from the Ant: phenomenon throughwhich it is apprehended by the senses, and by which it is interpretedand understood; -- so used in the philosophy of Kant and hisfollowers.
NICTITATE: To wink; to nictate. Nictitating membrance (Anat.), a thinmembrance, found in many animals at the inner angle, or beneath thelower lid, of the eye, and capable of being drawn across the eyeball;the third eyelid; the haw.
NEUROCORD: A cordlike organ composed of elastic fibers situated above theventral nervous cord of annelids, like the earthworm.-- Neu`ro*cor"dal, a.
NICKNAME: A name given in contempt, derision, or sportive familiarity; afamiliar or an opprobrious appellation.
N: N, the fourteenth letter of English alphabet, is a vocalconsonent, and, in allusion to its mode of formation, is called thedentinasal or linguanasal consonent. Its commoner sound is that heardin ran, done; but when immediately followed in the same word by thesound of g hard or k (as in single, sink, conquer), it usuallyrepresents the same sound as the digraph ng in sing, bring, etc. Thisis a simple but related sound, and is called the gutturo-nasalconsonent. See Guide to Pronunciation, §§ 243-246. The letter N cameinto English through the Latin and Greek from the Phoenician, whichprobably derived it from the Egyptian as the ultimate origin. It isetymologically most closely related to M. See M.
NEGATORY: Expressing denial; belonging to negation; negative. Carlyle.
NUMISMATOLOGY: The science which treats of coins and medals, in their relationto history; numismatics.
NESTLE: To house, as in a nest.
NORROY: The most northern of the English Kings-at-arms. See King-at-arms, under King.
NEMERTINA: An order of helminths usually having a long, slender, smooth,often bright-colored body, covered with minute vibrating cilia; --called also Nemertea, Nemertida, and Rhynchocæla.
NULLITY: Nonexistence; as, a decree of nullity of marriage is a decreethat no legal marriage exists.
NEOMORPH: A structure, part, or organ developed independently, that is,not derived from a similar structure, part, or organ, in a preexisting form.
NATCHNEE: An annual grass (Eleusine coracona), cultivated in India as afood plant.
NORMALCY: The quality, state, or fact of being normal; as, the point ofnormalcy. [R.]
NATAL: Presiding over nativity; as, natal Jove.
NOUNIZE: To change (an adjective, verb, etc.) into a noun. Earle.
NAGGING: Fault-finding; teasing; persistently annoying; as, a naggingtoothache. [Colloq.]
NERVATION: The arrangement of nerves and veins, especially those ofleaves; neuration.The outlines of the fronds of ferns, and their nervation, are frailcharacters if employed alone for the determination of existinggenera. J. D. Hooker.
NECROMANTIC: Conjuration. [R.]With all the necromantics of their art. Young.
NONOXYGENOUS: Without oxygen; characterized by the absence of oxygen; as, anonoxygenous alkaloid.
NIGHT-BLOOMING: Blooming in the night. Night-blooming cereus. (Bot.) See Noteunder Cereus.
NEWSBOY: A boy who distributes or sells newspaper.
NOVACULITE: A variety of siliceous slate, of which hones are made; razorstone; Turkey stone; hone stone; whet slate.
NASOLACHRYMAL: Connected with the lachrymal apparatus and the nose; as, thenasolachrymal, or lachrymal duct.
NETIFY: To render neat; to clean; to put in order. [R.] Chapman.
NEPHROLOGY: A treatise on, or the science which treats of, the kidneys, andtheir structure and functions.
NITRATE: A salt of nitric acid. Nitrate of silver, a white crystallinesalt (AgNO3), used in photography and as a cauterizing agent; --called also lunar caustic.
NORWEGIUM: A rare metallic element, of doubtful identification, said tooccur in the copper-nickel of Norway.
NORMANISM: A Norman idiom; a custom or expression peculiar to the Normans.M. Arnold.
NUT-BROWN: Brown as a nut long kept and dried. "The spicy nutbrown ale."Milton.
NIGHTINGALE: A small, plain, brown and gray European song bird (Luscinialuscinia). It sings at night, and is celebrated for the sweetness ofits song.
NOVEMBER: The eleventh month of the year, containing thirty days.
NEPHALIST: One who advocates or practices nephalism.
NEMATOID: of or pertaining to the Nematoidea.-- n.
NAPHTHALATE: A salt of naphthalic acid; a phthalate. [Obs.]
NEURAL: relating to the nerves or nervous system; taining to, situatedin the region of, or on the side with, the neural, or cerebro-spinal,axis; -- opposed to hemal. As applied to vertebrates, neural is thesame as dorsal; as applied to invertebrates it is usually the same asventral. Cf. Hemal. Neural arch (Anat.), the cartilaginous or bonyarch on the dorsal side of the centrum of the vertebra in a segmentof the spinal skeleton, usually inclosing a segment of the spinalcord.
NITROGLYCERIN: A liquid appearing like a heavy oil, colorless or yellowish,and consisting of a mixture of several glycerin salts of nitric acid,and hence more properly called glycerin nitrate. It is made by theaction of nitric acid on glycerin in the presence of sulphuric acid.It is extremely unstable and terribly explosive. A very dilutesolution is used in medicine as a neurotic under the name of glonion.[Written also nitroglycerine.]
NONYL: The hydrocarbon radical, C9H19, derived from nonane and formingmany compounds. Used also adjectively; as, nonyl alcohol.
NUPSON: A simpleton; a fool. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
NOVA: A new star, usually appearing suddenly, shining for a briefperiod, and then sinking into obscurity. Such appearances aresupposed to result from cosmic collisions, as of a dark star withinterstellar nebulosities. The most important modern novæ are: --No"va Co*ro"næ Bo`re*a"lis [1866]; No"va Cyg"ni [1876]; No"vaAn*dro"me*dæ [1885]; No"va Au*ri"gæ [1891-92]; No"va Per"se*i [1901].There are two novæ called Nova Persei. They are:(a) A small nova which appeared in 1881.(b) An extraordinary nova which appeared in Perseus in 1901. It wasfirst sighted on February 22, and for one night (February 23) was thebrightest star in the sky. By July it had almost disappeared, afterwhich faint surrounding nebulous masses were discovered, apparentlymoving radially outward from the star at incredible velocity.
NAPHTHOQUINONE: A yellow crystalline substance, C10H6O2, analogous to quinone,obtained by oxidizing naphthalene with chromic acid.
NEURO-: A combining denoting a nerve, of or pertaining to a nerve orthe nervous system.
NAUGHTILY: In a naughty manner; wickedly; perversely. Shak.
NATALS: One's birth, or the circumstances attending it. [Obs.] Fitz-Geffry.
NEUROPODOUS: Having the limbs on, or directed toward, the neural side, as inmost invertebrates; -- opposed to Ant: hæmapodous. G. Rolleston.
NUDGE: To touch gently, as with the elbow, in order to call attentionor convey intimation.
NYMPHOLEPSY: A species of demoniac enthusiasm or possession coming upon onewho had accidentally looked upon a nymph; ecstasy. [R.] De Quincey.The nympholepsy of some fond despair. Byron.
NINESCORE: Nine times twenty, or one hundred and eighty.-- n.
NONCONCUR: To dissent or refuse to concur.
NASH: Firm; stiff; hard; also, chilly. [Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
NEREIDIAN: Any annelid resembling Nereis, or of the family Lycoridæ orallied families.
NOTICEABLE: Capable of being observed; worthy of notice; likely to attractobservation; conspicous.A noticeable man, with large gray eyes. Wordsworth.
NOVATIAN: One of the sect of Novatius, or Novatianus, who held that thelapsed might not be received again into communion with the church,and that second marriages are unlawful.
NEUROSENSIFEROUS: Pertaining to, or forming, both nerves and sense organs.
NEURO-CENTRAL: Between the neural arch and the centrum of a vertebra; as, theneurocentral suture. Huxley.
NAKEDLY: In a naked manner; without covering or disguise; manifestly;simply; barely.
NONYLIC: Of, pertaining to, or designating, nonyl or its compounds; as,nonylic acid.
NUBBIN: A small or imperfect ear of maize. [Colloq. U. S.]
NONCHALANTLY: In a nonchalant, indifferent, or careless manner; coolly.
NEWSY: Full of news; abounding in information as to current events.[Colloq.]
NEARCTIC: Of or pertaining to a region of the earth's surface includingall of temperate and arctic North America and Greenland. In thegeographical distribution of animals, this region is marked off asthe habitat certain species.
NAPPINESS: The quality of having a nap; abundance of nap, as on cloth.
NEPTUNICENTRIC: As seen from Neptune, or having Neptune as a center; as,Neptunicentric longitude or force.
NIGHT-FARING: Going or traveling in the night. Gay.
NUB: To push; to nudge; also, to beckon. [Prov. Eng.]
NORTHUMBRIAN: Of or pertaining to Northumberland in England.-- n.
NESTFUL: As much or many as will fill a nest.
NOONDAY: Midday; twelve o'clock in the day; noon.
NONJURING: Not swearing allegiance; -- applied to the party in GreatBritain that would not swear allegiance to William and Mary, or theirsuccessors.
NOEMATACHOGRAPH: An instrument for determining and registering the duration ofmore or less complex operations of the mind. Dunglison.
NOSEGAY: A bunch of odorous and showy flowers; a bouquet; a posy. Pope.
NEDDY: A pet name for a donkey.
NOYAU: A cordial of brandy, etc., flavored with the kernel of thebitter almond, or of the peach stone, etc.
NONACQUIESCENCE: Refusal of acquiescence; failure to yield or comply.
NEONOMIAN: One who advocates adheres to new laws; esp. one who holds orbelieves that the gospel is a new law.
NAVIGABLE: Capable of being navigated; deep enough and wide enough toafford passage to vessels; as, a navigable river.
NEAR BEER: Any of various malt liquors (see Citation).
NOL-PROS: To discontinue by entering a nolle prosequi; to decline toprosecute.
NONJURORISM: The doctrines, or action, of the Nonjurors.
NIHILISTIC: Of, pertaining to, or characterized by, nihilism.
NAGYAGITE: A mineral of blackish lead-gray color and metallic luster,generally of a foliated massive structure; foliated tellurium. It isa telluride of lead and gold.
NOCK: The upper fore corner of a boom sail or of a trysail.
NEOPLASIA: Growth or development of new material; neoplasty.
NOTELESS: Not attracting notice; not conspicuous.Noteless as the race from which he sprung. Sir W. Scott.
NAPU: A very small chevrotain (Tragulus Javanicus), native of Java.It is about the size of a hare, and is noted for its agility inleaping. Called also Java musk deer, pygmy musk deer, and deerlet.
NEGOTIATRIX: A woman who negotiates. Miss Edgeworth.
NOEMICS: The science of the understanding; intellectual science.
NAPHTHOL: Any one of a series of hydroxyl derivatives of naphthalene,analogous to phenol. In general they are crystalline substances witha phenol (carbolic) odor. Naphthol blue, Naphthol orange, Naphtholyellow (Chem.), brilliant dyestuffs produced from certain complexnitrogenous derivatives of naphthol or naphthoquinone.
NOTORIOUS: Generally known and talked of by the public; universallybelieved to be true; manifest to the world; evident; -- usually in anunfavorable sense; as, a notorious thief; a notorious crime or vice.Your goodness, Since you provoke me, shall be most notorious. Shak.
NOMOGRAPHY: A treatise on laws; an exposition of the form proper for laws.
NASOFRONTAL: of or pertaining to the nose and the front of the head; as, theembryonic nasofrontal process which forms the anterior boundary ofthe mouth.
NONPAREIL: A size of type next smaller than minion and next larger thanagate (or ruby).
NUDIBRANCHIATA: A division of opisthobranchiate mollusks, having no shellexcept while very young. The gills are naked and situated upon theback or sides. See Ceratobranchia.
NEPOTISM: Undue attachment to relations; favoritism shown to members ofone's family; bestowal of patronage in consideration of relationship,rather than of merit or of legal claim.From nepotism Alexander V. was safe; for he was without kindred orrelatives. But there was another perhaps more fatal nepotism, whichturned the tide of popularity against him -- the nepotism of hisorder. Milman.
NEW ZEALAND: A group of islands in the South Pacific Ocean. New Zealandflax. (a) (Bot.) A tall, liliaceous herb (Phormium tenax), havingvery long, sword-shaped, distichous leaves which furnish a fine,strong fiber very valuable for cordage and the like. (b) The fiberitself.-- New Zealand tea (Bot.), a myrtaceous shrub (Leptospermumscoparium) of New Zealand and Australia, the leaves of which are usedas a substitute for tea.
NUCLEATED: Having a nucleus; nucleate; as, nucleated cells.
NEVERMORE: Never again; at no time hereafter. Testament of Love. Tyndale.Where springtime of the Hesperides Begins, but endeth nevermore.Longfellow.
NATTY: Neat; tidy; spruce. [Colloq.] -- Nat"ti*ly, adv.-- Nat"ti*ness, n.
NATCHEZ: A tribe of Indians who formerly lived near the site of the cityof Natchez, Mississippi. In 1729 they were subdued by the French; thesurvivors joined the Creek Confederacy.
NUCAMENT: A catkin or ament; the flower cluster of the hazel, pine,willow, and the like.
NONINHABITANT: One who is not an inhabitant; a stranger; a foreigner; anonresident.
NUCLEIN: A constituent of the nuclei of all cells. It is a colorlessamorphous substance, readily soluble in alkaline fluids andespecially characterized by its comparatively large content ofphosphorus. It also contains nitrogen and sulphur.
NATALOIN: A bitter crystalline substance constituting the essentialprinciple of Natal aloes. Cf. Aloon.
NIDULITE: A Silurian fossil, formerly supposed to consist of eggs.
NORITE: A granular crystalline rock consisting essentially of atriclinic feldspar (as labradorite) and hypersthene.
NOUN: A word used as the designation or appellation of a creature orthing, existing in fact or in thought; a substantive.
NIGRESCENT: Growing black; changing to a black color; approaching toblackness. Johnson.
NAUSCOPY: The power or act of discovering ships or land at considerabledistances.
NEUFCHATEL: A kind of soft sweet-milk cheese; -- so called from Neufchâtel-en-Bray in France.
NONCONTAGIOUS: Not contagious; not catching; not communicable by contact.-- Non`con*ta"gious*ness, n.
NEPHROTOMY: Extraction of stone from the kidney by cutting.
NITROQUINOL: A hypothetical nitro derivative of quinol or hydroquinone, notknown in the free state, but forming a well defined series ofderivatives.
NYMPH: A goddess of the mountains, forests, meadows, or waters.Where were ye, nymphs, when the remorseless deep Closed o'er the headof your loved Lycidas Milton.
NOTE PAPER: Writing paper, not exceeding in size, when folded once, five byeight inches.
NEEDLY: Like a needle or needles; as, a needly horn; a needly beard. R.D. Blackmore.
NOMINEE: A person named, or designated, by another, to any office, duty,or position; one nominated, or proposed, by others for office or forelection to office.
NEAT: Cattle of the genus Bos, as distinguished from horses, sheep,and goats; an animal of the genus Bos; as, a neat's tongue; a neat'sfoot. Chaucer.Wherein the herds[men] were keeping of their neat. Spenser.The steer, the heifer, and the calf Are all called neat. Shak.A neat and a sheep of his own. Tusser.Neat's-foot, an oil obtained by boiling the feet of neat cattle. Itis used to render leather soft and pliable.
NIBELUNGENLIED: A great medieval German epic of unknown authorship containingtraditions which refer to the Burgundians at the time of Attila(called Etzel in the poem) and mythological elements pointing toheathen times.
NOW: Existing at the present time; present. [R.] "Our nowhappiness." Glanvill.
NEOPLATONIC: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, Neoplatonism or theNeoplatonists.
NYCTIBUNE: A South American bird of the genus Nyctibius, allied to thegoatsuckers.
NEWTONIAN: Of or pertaining to Sir Isaac Newton, or his discoveries.Newtonian philosophy, the philosophy of Sir Isaac Newton; -- appliedto the doctrine of the universe as expounded in Newton's "Principia,"to the modern or experimental philosophy (as opposed to the theoriesof Descartes and others), and, most frequently, to the mathematicaltheory of universal gravitation.-- Newtonian telescope (Astron.), a reflecting telescope, in whichrays from the large speculum are received by a plane mirror placeddiagonally in the axis, and near the open end of the tube, and thrownat right angles toward one side of the tube, where the image isformed and viewed through the eyeplace.-- Newtonian theory of light. See Note under Light.
NEIGHBOR: Near to another; adjoining; adjacent; next; neighboring. "Theneighbor cities." Jer. l. 40. "The neighbor room." Shak.
NYE: A brood or flock of pheasants.
NONPRESENTATION: Neglect or failure to present; state of not being presented.
NETTING: A network of ropes used for various purposes, as for holdingthe hammocks when not in use, also for stowing sails, and forhoisting from the gunwale to the rigging to hinder an enemy fromboarding. Totten. Netting needle, a kind of slender shuttle used innetting. See Needle, n., 3.
NIGHNESS: The quality or state of being nigh. [R.] "Nighness of blood."Holished.
NEPA: A genus of aquatic hemipterus insects. The species feed uponother insects and are noted for their voracity; -- called alsoscorpion bug and water scorpion.
NEURON: The brain and spinal cord; the cerebro-spinal axis;myelencephalon. B. G. Wilder.
NEPHRIDIUM: A segmental tubule; one of the tubules of the primitiveurinogenital organs; a segmental organ. See Illust. under Loeven'slarva.
NONAGED: Having the quality of nonage; being a minor; immature. W.Browne.
NOLITION: Adverse action of will; unwillingness; -- opposed to Ant:volition.A nolition and a direct enmity against the lust. Jer. Taylor.
NARWHAL: An arctic cetacean (Monodon monocerous), about twenty feetlong. The male usually has one long, twisted, pointed canine tooth,or tusk projecting forward from the upper jaw like a horn, whence itis called also sea unicorn, unicorn fish, and unicorn whale.Sometimes two horns are developed, side by side.
NEST: An aggregated mass of any ore or mineral, in an isolated state,within a rock.
NEPOTIC: Of or pertaining to npotism.The nepotic ambition of the ruling pontiff. Milman.
NICOTIANA: A genus of American and Asiatic solanaceous herbs, with viscidfoliage and funnel-shaped blossoms. Several species yield tobacco.See Tobacco.
NEO-LAMARCKISM: Lamarckism as revived, modified, and expounded by recentbiologists, esp. as maintaining that the offspring inheritscharacters acquired by the parent from change of environment, use ordisuse of parts, etc.; -- opposed of Neo-Darwinism (which see,above). -- Ne`o-La*marck"i*an, a. & n.
NONSANE: Unsound; not perfect; as, a person of nonsane memory.Blackstone.
NASO-: A combining form denoting pertaining to, or connected with, thenose; as, nasofrontal.
NERVE-SHAKEN: Affected by a tremor, or by a nervous disease; weakened;overcome by some violent influence or sensation; shoked.
NONOBEDIENCE: Neglect of obedience; failure to obey.
NYMPHEAN: Of, pertaining to, or appropriate to, nymphs; inhabited bynymphs; as, a nymphean cave.
NUPTIAL: Of or pertaining to marriage; done or used at a wedding; as,nuptial rites and ceremonies.Then, all in heat, They light the nuptial torch. Milton.
NITROSO-: (. (Chem.) A prefix (also used adjectively) designating thegroup or radical NO, called the nitroso group, or its compounds.
NERO: A Roman emperor notorius for debauchery and barbarous cruelty;hence, any profligate and cruel ruler or merciless tyrant.-- Ne*ro"ni*an, a.
NUCLEIFORM: Formed like a nucleus or kernel.
NIDIFICATION: The act or process of building a nest.
NIGHLY: In a near relation in place, time, degree, etc.; within alittle; almost. [Obs.]A cube and a sphere ... nighly of the same bigness. Locke.
NOVITIOUS: Newly invented; recent; new. [Obs.] Bp. Pearson.
NAUGHTLY: Naughtily; wrongly. [Obs.]because my parents naughtly brought me up. Mir. for Mag.
NITRATINE: A mineral occurring in transparent crystals, usually of awhite, sometimes of a reddish gray, or lemon-yellow, color; nativesodium nitrate. It is used in making nitric acid and for manure.Called also soda niter.
NOTARIAL: Of or pertaining to a notary; done or taken by a notary; as, anotarial seal; notarial evidence or attestation.
NEOCARIDA: The modern, or true, Crustacea, as distinguished from theMerostomata.
NARROW-MINDED: Of narrow mental scope; illiberal; mean.-- Nar"row-mind`ed*ness, n.
NONDECIDUATE: Characterized by the absence of a decidua; indeciduate.
NORTHER: A wind from the north; esp., a strong and cold north wind inTexas and the vicinity of the Gulf of Mexico.
NECESSITATTION: The act of making necessary, or the state of being madenecessary; compulsion. [R.] bp. Bramhall.
NIHILIST: A member of a secret association (esp. in Russia), which isdevoted to the destruction of the present political, religious, andsocial institutions.
NUMISMATICS: The science of coins and medals.
NIDULATE: To make a nest, as a bird. [R.] Cockeram.
NATATORIOUS: Adapted for swimming; -- said of the legs of certain insects.
NORSEMAN: One of the ancient Scandinavians; a Northman.
NUDIBRACHIATE: Having tentacles without vibratile cilia. Carpenter.
NERKA: The most important salmon of Alaska (Oncorhinchus nerka),ascending in spring most rivers and lakes from Alaska to Oregon,Washington, and Idaho; --called also red salmon, redfish, blueback,and sawqui.
NOCTILUCIN: A fatlike substance in certain marine animals, to which theyowe their phosphorescent properties.
NEURIDIN: a nontoxic base, C5H14N2, found in the putrescent matters offlesh, fish, decaying cheese, etc.
NOUGAT: A cake, sweetmeat, or confectión made with almonds or othernuts.
NIHIL: Nothing. Nihil album Etym: [L., white nothing] (Chem.), oxideof zinc. See under Zinc.-- Nihil debet Etym: [L., he owes nothing] (Law), the general issuein certain actions of debt.-- Nihil dicit Etym: [L., he says nothing] (Law), a declinature bythe defendant to plead or answer. Tomlins.
NITROGENOUS: of, pertaining to, or resembling, nitrogen; as, a nitrogenousprinciple; nitrogenous compounds. Nitrogenous foods. See 2d Noteunder Food, n., 1.
NUCHA: The back or upper part of the neck; the nape.
NATIONALLY: In a national manner or way; as a nation. "The jews ... beingnationally espoused to God by covenant." South.
NONNECESSITY: Absence of necessity; the quality or state of beingunnecessary.
NEBULIZATION: The act or process of nebulizing; atomization.
NULLIFIER: One who nullifies or makes void; one who maintains the right tonullify a contract by one of the parties.
NEEM TREE: An Asiatic name for Melia Azadirachta, and M. Azedarach. SeeMargosa.
NETHER: Situated down or below; lying beneath, or in the lower part;having a lower position; belonging to the region below; lower; under;-- opposed to upper.'Twixt upper, nether, and surrounding fires. Milton.This darksome nether world her light Doth dim with horror anddeformity. Spenser.All my nether shape thus grew transformed. Milton.
NEO-SCHOLASTICISM: The modern revival of the Scholastic philosophy, esp. of thatof Thomas Aquinas, with critical revision to suit the exigencies ofthe general advance in learning. The Neo-Scholastic movement receiveda great impetus from Leo XIII.'s interest in it.
NOBLEWOMAN: A female of noble rank; a peeress.
NUMBER: The distinction of objects, as one, or more than one (in somelanguages, as one, or two, or more than two), expressed (usually) bya difference in the form of a word; thus, the singular number and theplural number are the names of the forms of a word indicating theobjects denoted or referred to by the word as one, or as more thanone.
NAVELWORT: A European perennial succulent herb (Cotyledon umbilicus),having round, peltate leaves with a central depression; -- alsocalled pennywort, and kidneywort.
NECTARIFEROUS: Secreting nectar; -- said of blossoms or their parts.
NOTABLE: One of a number of persons, before the revolution of 1789,chiefly of the higher orders, appointed by the king to constitute arepresentative body.
NEMOPHILY: Fondness for forest scenery; love of the woods. [R.]
NEUROPODIUM: The ventral lobe or branch of a parapodium.
NITROBENZENE: A yellow aromatic liquid (C6H5.NO2), produced by the action ofnitric acid on benzene, and called from its odor imitation oil ofbitter almonds, or essence of mirbane. It is used in perfumery, andis manufactured in large quantities in the preparation of aniline.Fornerly called also nitrobenzol.
NASALIZE: To render nasal, as sound; to insert a nasal or sound in.
NEIGHBORING: Living or being near; adjacent; as, the neighboring nations orcountries.
NEUROLOGY: The branch of science which treats of the nervous system.
NAIL-HEADED: Having a head like that of a nail; formed so as to resemble thehead of a nail. Nail-headed characters, arrowheaded or cuneiformcharacters. See under Arrowheaded.-- Nail-headed molding (Arch.), an ornament consisting of a seriesof low four-sided pyramids resembling the heads of large nails; --called also nail-head molding, or nail-head. It is the same as thesimplest form of dogtooth. See Dogtooth.
NUISANCE: That which annoys or gives trouble and vexation; that which isoffensive or noxious.
NAMATION: A distraining or levying of a distress; an impounding. Burrill.
NITROSYL: the radical NO, called also the nitroso group. The term issometimes loosely used to designate certain nitro compounds; as,nitrosyl sulphuric acid. Used also adjectively.
NESS: A promontory; a cape; a headland. Hakluyt.
NATIVISM: The doctrine of innate ideas, or that the mind possesses formsof thought independent of sensation.
NIBLICK: A kind of golf stick used to lift the ball out of holes, ruts,etc.
NOTSELF: The negative of self. "A cognizance of notself." Sir. W.Hamilton.
NUMBNESS: The condition of being numb; that state of a living body inwhich it loses, wholly or in part, the power of feeling or motion.
NONDEPOSITION: A failure to deposit or throw down.
NEUTRALIZATION: The act or process by which an acid and a base are combined insuch proportions that the resulting compound is neutral. See Neutral,a., 4.
NEMATOGNATHI: An order of fishes having barbels on the jaws. It includes thecatfishes, or siluroids. See Siluroid.
NOSING: That part of the treadboard of a stair which projects over theriser; hence, any like projection, as the projecting edge of amolding.
NUNCIATURE: The office of a nuncio. Clarendon.
NITROGENIZE: To combine, or impregnate, with nitrogen or its compounds.
NEO-HELLENISM: Hellenism as surviving or revival in modern times; the practiceor pursuit of ancient Greek ideals in modern life, art, orliterature, as in the Renaissance.
NATIVE STEEL: A sort of steel which has been found where a burning coal seamhad reduced and carbonized adjacent iron ore.
NERRE: Nearer. [Obs.] [Written also neer, ner.] Chaucer. Never theneer, never the nearer; no nearer. [Obs.]
NESCIENCE: Want of knowledge; ignorance; agnosticism.God fetched it about for me, in that absence and nescience of mine.Bp. Hall.
NONIMPORTING: Not importing; not bringing from foreign countries.
NAKE: ,v.t. To make naked. [Obs.] Chaucer.Come, be ready, nake your swords. Old Play.
NORLANDER: A northener; a person from the north country.
NOBLE-MINDED: Having a noble mind; honorable; magnanimous.-- No"ble-mind`ed*ness, n.
NEEDILY: In a needy condition or manner; necessarily. Chaucer.
NEMESIS: The goddess of retribution or vengeance; hence, retributivejustice personified; divine vengeance.This is that ancient doctrine of nemesis who keeps watch in theuniverse, and lets no offense go unchastised. Emerson.
NASICORNOUS: Bearing a horn, or horns, on the nose, as the rhinoceros.
NOVILUNAR: Of or pertaining to the new moon. [R.]
NONINTERVENTION: The state or habit of not intervening or interfering; as, thenonintervention of one state in the affairs of another.
NON EST FACTUM: The plea of the general issue in an action of debt on bond.
NONREGENT: A master of arts whose regency has ceased. See Regent.
NIBELUNGS: In German mythology, the children of the mist, a race of dwarfsor demonic beings, the original possessors of the famous hoard andring won by Siegfrid; also, the Burgundian kings in theNibelungenlied.
NORMAN: A wooden bar, or iron pin. W. C. Russell.
NAPPY: Having a nap or pile; downy; shaggy. Holland.
NONRESIDENT: Not residing in a particular place, on one's own estate, or inone's proper place; as, a nonresident clergyman or proprietor oflands.
NUCULA: A genus of small marine bivalve shells, having a pearlyinterior.
NASCENT: Evolving; being evolved or produced. Nascent state (Chem.), thesupposed instantaneous or momentary state of an uncombined atom orradical just separated from one compound acid, and not yet unitedwith another, -- a hypothetical condition implying peculiarly activechemical properties; as, hydrogen in the nascent state is a strongreducer.
NECRONITE: Fetid feldspar, a mineral which, when struck, exhales a fetidodor.
NARCEINE: An alkaloid found in small quantities in opium, and extractedas a white crystalline substance of a bitter astringent taste. It isa narcotic. Called also narceia.
NEUROPTERA: An order of hexapod insects having two pairs of large,membranous, net-veined wings. The mouth organs are adapted forchewing. They feed upon other insects, and undergo a completemetamorphosis. The ant-lion, hellgamite, and lacewing fly areexamples. Formerly, the name was given to a much more extensivegroup, including the true Neuroptera and the Pseudoneuroptera.
NE EXEAT: A writ to restrain a person from leaving the country, or thejurisdiction of the court. The writ was originally applicable topurposes of state, but is now an ordinary process of courts ofequity, resorted to for the purpose of obtaining bail, or security toabide a decree. Kent.
NOURSLE: To nurse; to rear; to bring up. [Obs.] [Written also nosel,nousel, nousle, nowsle, nusle, nuzzle, etc.]She noursled him till years he raught. Spenser.
NAMER: One who names, or calls by name.
NIGGER: A negro; -- in vulgar derision or depreciation.
NORTELRY: Nurture; education; culture; bringing up. [Obs.]Nortelry . . . learned at the nunnery. Chaucer.
NISAN: The first month of the jewish ecclesiastical year, formerlyanswering nearly to the month of April, now to March, of theChristian calendar. See Abib.
NONJOINDER: The omission of some person who ought to have been made aplaintiff or defendant in a suit, or of some cause of action whichought to be joined.
NARROWNESS: The condition or quality of being narrow.
NEMOROUS: Woody. [R.]Paradise itself was but a kind of nemorous temple. Evelyn.
NECTAREAL: Of or pertaining to a nectary.
NEW-YEAR: Of or pertaining to, or suitable for, the commencement of theyear; as, New-year gifts or odes.
NECESSITARIANISM: The doctrine of philosophical necessity; the doctrine thatresults follow by invariable sequence from causes, and esp. that thewill is not free, but that human actions and choices resultinevitably from motives; deteminism. M. Arnold.
NEBULATION: The condition of being nebulated; also, a clouded, or ill-defined, color mark.
NIOBIUM: A later name of columbium. See Columbium.
NIGGARD: A person meanly close and covetous; one who spends grudgingly;a stingy, parsimonous fellow; a miser. Chaucer.A penurious niggard of his wealth. Milton.Be niggards of advice on no pretense. Pope.
NO: Not any; not one; none.Let there be no strife ... between me and thee. Gen. xiii. 8.That goodness is no name, and happiness no dream. Byron.
NAMBY-PAMBY: Talk or writing which is weakly sentimental or affectedlypretty. Macaulay.
NUNATAK: In Greenland, an insular hill or mountain surrounded by an icesheet.
NE: Not; never. [Obs.]He never yet no villany ne said. Chaucer.
NARROW: Formed (as a vowel) by a close position of some part of thetongue in relation to the palate; or (according to Bell) by a tensecondition of the pharynx; -- distinguished from wide; as e (eve) andoo (food), etc., from ì (ìll) and oo (foot), etc. See Guide toPronunciation, § 13.
NAPOLEONIC: Of or pertaining to Napoleon I., or his family; resembling, orhaving the qualities of, Napoleon I. Lowell.
NEEDLEFUL: As much thread as is used in a needle at one time.
NONCONFORMIST: One who does not conform to an established church; especially,one who does not conform to the established church of England; adissenter.
NABK: The edible berries of the Zizyphys Lotus, a tree of NorthernAfrica, and Southwestern Europe. [Written also nubk.] See Lotus (b),and Sadr.
NATURALLY: In a natural manner or way; according to the usual course ofthings; spontaneously.
NATHMORE: Not the more; never the more. [Obs.] penser.
NONELECTRIC: A substance that is not an electric; that which transmitselectricity, as a metal.
NITROMETHANE: A nitro derivative of methane obtained as a mobile liquid; --called also nitrocarbol.
NOTIONALLY: In mental apprehension; in conception; not in reality.Two faculties . . . notionally or really distinct. Norris.
NITROPHNOL: Any one of a series of nitro derivatives of phenol. They areyellow oily or crystalline substances and have well-defined acidproperties, as picric acid.
NONLIMITATION: Want of limitation; failure to limit.
NEOPLATONIST: One who held to Neoplatonism; a member of the Neoplatonicschool.
NOCTILIONID: A South American bat of the genus Noctilio, having cheekpouches and large incisor teeth.
NOTORIETY: The quality or condition of being notorious; the state of beinggenerally or publicly known; -- commonly used in an unfavorablesense; as, the notoriety of a crime.They were not subjects in their own nature so exposed to publicnotoriety. Addison.
NAPHTHYLAMINE: One of two basic amido derivatives of naphthalene, C10H7.NH2,forming crystalline solids.
NEITHER: Not either; not the one or the other.Which of them shall I take Both one or neither Neither can beenjoyed, If both remain alive. Shak.He neither loves, Nor either cares for him. Shak.
NEGRITA: A blackish fish (Hypoplectrus nigricans), of the Sea-bassfamily. It is a native of the West Indies and Florida.
NUCLEOLAR: Of or pertaining to the nucleolus of a cell.
NEOPLASM: A new formation or tissue, the product of morbid action.
NEOLITHIC: Of or pertaining to, or designating, an era characterized bylate remains in stone.The Neolithic era includes the latter half of the "Stone age;" thehuman relics which belong to it are associated with the remains ofanimals not yet extinct. The kitchen middens of Denmark, the lakedwellings of Switzerland, and the stockaded islands, or "crannogs,"of the British Isles, belong to this era. Lubbock.
NAEVUS: A spot or mark on the skin of children when born; a birthmark;-- usually applied to vascular tumors, i. e., those consisting mainlyof blood vessels, as dilated arteries, veins, or capillaries.
NOOK-SHOTTEN: Full of nooks, angles, or corners. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]That nook-shotten isle of Albion. Shak.
NEMATOCALYX: One of a peculiar kind of cups, or calicles, found uponhydroids of the family Plumularidæ. They contain nematocysts. SeePlumularia.
NAUROPOMETER: An instrument for measuring the amount which a ship heels atsea.
NOSTRIL: One of the external openings of the nose, which give passage tothe air breathed and to secretions from the nose and eyes; one of theanterior nares.
NORFOLK JACKET: A kind of loose-fitting plaited jacket, having a loose belt.
NASUTNESS: Quickness of scent; hence, nice discernment; acuteness. [Obs.]Dr. H. More.
NOMENCLATURAL: Pertaining or according to a nomenclature.
NEWSPAPER: A sheet of paper printed and distributed, at stated intervals,for conveying intelligence of passing events, advocating opinions,etc.; a public print that circulates news, advertisements,proceedings of legislative bodies, public announcements, etc.
NUMISMATIST: One skilled in numismatics; a numismatologist.
NON PROSEQUITUR: A judgment entered against the plaintiff in a suit where hedoes not appear to prosecute. See Nolle prosequi.
NOTOTREMA: The pouched, or marsupial, frog of South America.
NONABILITY: An exception taken against a plaintiff in a cause, when he isunable legally to commence a suit.
NOAH: A patriarch of Biblical history, in the time of the Deluge.Noah's ark. (a) (Zoöl.) A marine bivalve shell (Arca Noæ), whichsomewhat resembles an ark, or ship, in form. (b) A child's toy,consisting of an ark-shaped box containing many different woodenanimals.
NONCONDUCTION: The quality of not being able to conduct or transmit; failureto conduct.
NEGRITIC: Of or pertaining to negroes; composed of negroes. Keary.
NARCOTIZE: To imbue with, or subject to the influence of, a narcotic; toput into a state of narcosis.
NECROLOGY: An account of deaths, or of the dead; a register of deaths; acollection of obituary notices.
NONPROFICIENCY: Want of proficiency; failure to make progress.
NATIVELY: By natural or original condition; naturally; originally.
NAUTIFORM: Shaped like the hull of a ship.
NORTHING: Distance northward from any point of departure or of reckoning,measured on a meridian; -- opposed to Ant: southing.
NOON: No. See the Note under No. [Obs.]
NASAL: Of or pertaining to the nose.
NONPHOTOBIOTIC: Capable of living without light; as, nonphotobiotic plantcells, or cells which habitually live in darkness.
NEMATOIDEA: An order of worms, having a long, round, and generally smoothbody; the roundworms. they are mostly parasites. Called alsoNematodea, and Nematoda.
NONJUROR: One of those adherents of James II. who refused to take theoath of allegiance to William and Mary, or to their successors, afterthe revolution of 1688; a Jacobite.
NODOSE: Having nodes or prominences; having the alternate jointsenlarged, as the antennæ of certain insects.
NOTORNIS: A genus of birds allied to the gallinules, but havingrudimentary wings and incapable of flight. Notornis Mantelli wasfirst known as a fossil bird of New Zealand, but subsequently a fewindividuals were found living on the southern island. It is supposedto be now nearly or quite extinct.
NAUSEATION: The act of nauseating, or the state of being nauseated.
NARTHEX: A tall umbelliferous plant (Ferula communis). See Giant fennel,under Fennel.
NOVICESHIP: The state of being a novice; novitiate.
NEEDS: Of necessity; necessarily; indispensably; -- often with must,and equivalent to of need.A man must needs love mauger his head. Chaucer.And he must needs go through Samaria. John iv. 4.He would needs know the cause of his reulse. Sir J. Davies.
NOPALRY: A plantation of the nopal for raising the cochineal insect.
NATURIST: One who believes in, or conforms to, the theory of naturism.Boyle.
NOTHINGARIAN: One of no certain belief; one belonging to no particular sect.
NITROSYLIC: Of, pertaining to, or containing, nitrosyl; as, nitrosylicacid.
NEOLOGIST: of or pertaining to neology; neological.
NUX VOMICA: The seed of Strychnos Nuxvomica, a tree which abounds on theMalabar and Coromandel coasts of the East Indies. From this seed thedeadly poisons known as strychnine and brucine are obtained. Theseeds are sometimes called Quaker buttons.
NORTHMAN: One of the inhabitants of the north of Europe; esp., one of theancient Scandinavians; a Norseman.
NUBIAN: Of or pertaining to Nubia in Eastern Africa.-- n.
NOCTILUCA: That which shines at night; -- a fanciful name for phosphorus.
NERVOUSNESS: State or quality of being nervous.
NECKLACED: Wearing a necklace; marked as with a necklace.The hooded and the necklaced snake. Sir W. Jones.
NONRUMINANT: Not ruminating; as, a nonruminant animal.
NEOPLASTY: Restoration of a part by granulation, adhesive inflammation, orautoplasty.
NIGGARDOUS: Niggardly. [Obs.]Covetous gathering and niggardous keeping. Sir T. More.
NEED: To be in want of; to have cause or occasion for; to lack; torequire, as supply or relief.Other creatures all day long Rove idle, unemployed, and less needrest. Milton.
NEURAPOPHYSIAL: of or pertaining to a neurapophysis.
NEODYMIUM: An elementary substance which forms one of the constituents ofdidymium. Symbol Nd. Atomic weight 140.8.
NITROLIC: of, derived from, or designating, a nitrol; as, a nitrolicacid.
NOCTIDIAL: Comprising a night and a day; a noctidial day. [R.] Holder.
NOGGING: Rough brick masonry used to fill in the interstices of a woodenframe, in building.
NIGHTJAR: A goatsucker, esp. the European species. See Illust. ofGoatsucker.
NYMPHALES: An extensive family of butterflies including the nymphs, thesatyrs, the monarchs, the heliconias, and others; -- called alsobrush-footed butterflies.
NECROSE: To affect with necrosis; to unergo necrosis. Quain.
NOBILITATE: To make noble; to ennoble; to exalt. [Obs.]
NET-VEINED: Having veins, or nerves, reticulated or netted; as, a net-veined wing or leaf.
NULLIFY: To make void; to render invalid; to deprive of legal force orefficacy.Such correspondence would at once nullify the conditions of theprobationary system. I. Taylor.
NOMOPELMOUS: Having a separate and simple tendon to flex the first toe, orhallux, as do passerine birds.
NOMBLES: The entrails of a deer; the umbles. [Written also numbles.]Johnson.
NAYWORD: A byword; a proverb; also, a watchword. [Obs.] hak.
NONVOCAL: Not vocal; destitute of tone.-- n.
NIDGET: A fool; an idiot, a coward. [Obs.] Camden.
NICENE: Of or pertaining to Nice, a town of Asia Minor, or to theecumenial council held there A. D. 325. Nicene Creed (, a summary ofChristian faith, composed and adopted by the Council of Nice, againstArianism, A. D. 325, altered and confirmed by the Council ofConstantinople, A. D. 381, and by subsequent councils.
NEIGHBORLY: Apropriate to the relation of neighbors; having frequent orfamiliar intercourse; kind; civil; social; friendly.-- adv.
NECESSITARIAN: Of or pertaining to the doctrine of philosophical necessity inregard to the origin and existence of things, especially as appliedto the actings or choices of the will; -- opposed to libertarian.
NOSE: The prominent part of the face or anterior extremity of thehead containing the nostrils and olfactory cavities; the olfactoryorgan. See Nostril, and Olfactory organ under Olfactory.
NOMINATIVAL: Of or pertaining to the nominative case.
NONCLAIM: A failure to make claim within the time limited by law;omission of claim.
NAPERY: Table linen; also, linen clothing, or linen in general. [Obs.]Gayton.
NARCOTINE: An alkaloid found in opium, and extracted as a whitecrystalline substance, tasteless and less poisonous than morphine; --called also narcotia.
NIGGARDLY: Meanly covetous or avarcious in dealing with others; stingy;niggard.Where the owner of the house will be bountiful, it is not for thesteward to be niggardly. Bp. Hall.
NEUROSKELETAL: Of or pertaining to the neuroskeleton. [R.] Owen.
NUNDINATION: Traffic at fairs; marketing; buying and selling. [Obs.]Common nundination of pardons. Abp. Bramhall.
NONILLION: According to the French and American notation, a thousandoctillions, or a unit with thirty ciphers annexed; according to theEnglish notation, a million octillions, or a unit with fifty-fourciphers annexed. See the Note under Numeration.
NAPHTHAZARIN: A dyestuff, resembling alizarin, obtained from naphthoquinoneas a red crystalline substance with a bright green, metallic luster;-- called also naphthalizarin.
NITRIDE: A binary compound of nitrogen with a more metallic element orradical; as, boric nitride.
NOCTURNAL: An instrument formerly used for taking the altitude of thestars, etc., at sea. I. Watts.
NEGRESS: A black woman; a female negro.
NIGGLE: To trifle with; to deceive; to mock. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
NOTOCHORDAL: Of or pertaining to the notochord; having a notochord.
NITRANILINE: Any one of a series of nitro derivatives of aniline. In generalthey are yellow crystalline substances.
